div.p: A LETTER OF FRANCESCO REDI Concerning Some Objections made upon his OBSERVATIONS About VIPERS: Written to Monieur BOURDELOT Abbot, and Lord of Conde and St. Leger.
And Monieur ALEXANDER MORS.
Printed in Italian at Florence, 1670.
Together with The SEQUEL of NEW EXPERIMENTS upon VIPERS, and a Diertation upon their Poyon: Serving for a Reply to a Letter written by Signor Francico Redi to M. Bourdelot, and M. Morus.

p.hi: Written in French by Moye Charas. Now likewie Englihed.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by T. R. for John Martyn Printer to the Royal Society, at the Bell in S. Pauls Churchyard, 1673.

div.head: A LETTER OF FRANCESCO REDI, Concerning ome Objections made upon his Obervations about Vipers.
Written to Monieur BOURDELOT, AND Monieur ALEXANDER MORUS.
div.p: FROM your liberality I have received the Book entituled NEW EXPERIMENTS upon VIPERS, learnedly compoed by thoe noble Virtuoi, who during ome months had met in the Houe of M. Charas for that purpoe. I have read it over more then once with great contentment, plainly finding that thoe Worthy perons have not crupled by their eminent labours to confirm the Truth of thoe Obervations, which I alo had made touching VIPERS, until the year 1664.

And indeed I think my elf much obliged to their ingenuity, and do frankly acknowledge, that whatever worth that rude and plain piece of mine may have, it hath received it from the honourable tetimonies, given to it in France, where all the excellent Sciences and Arts do highly florih, to the admiration of thoe that profes them in the other parts of Europe.

I intreat you, Sirs, that you would do me the favour to repreent upon occaion thee my candid and cordial entiments, and withall to declare the high eteem I have for that Book the authority of which is o venerable with me, that, having found therein ome few things directly contrary to my own Experiments, I have often doubted of my elf, and been almot ready to believe, that I dream'd when I made, and when I wrote them. But ome of my Learned Friends, that were frequently preent at thoe my Operations, have laughed at me for that pronenes of my belief, and between jet and earnet aur'd me, that thoe Experiments had by no means o ucceeded with me in a dream. Notwithtanding which, without any regard to their aeverations, I reolved to iterate
and reiterate them, and that with o great and careful diligence, that I hould greatly injure my elf and Truth, if I hould not freely and candidly tell you, that all thoe four or five Experiments, which to thoe Gentlemen in France have not ucceded, do ucceed with me in Italy without fail, as they were formerly recorded by me; on the contrary, thoe will not ucceed with me that have been made in France and are contrary to mine.

And ince you may perhaps have the curioity as to deire to know of what kind they are, I hall here give you a brief account of them; auring my elf, that it will be acceptable to all the Lovers of Truth, but epecially to the Authors of the Book of the New Experiments, who have been induced to write by no other motive then the ole deire either to confirm or to find the Truth of a matter o curious, of which o many undertanding men have written.

In my Letter then of the Obervations about Vipers, addreed to the Illutrious Lorenzo Magalotti, peaking of the Poion of thoe creatures, both what it is, and in what part of the Body it reideth, I affirm'd
(as I affirm till) that the Poion of a Viper is nothing ele then a certain yellowih liquor, which lodgeth in the veicles that cover the greatet teeth of the Viper; and that that Juice is not only poionous, when it is ejected by the live Viper when he biteth, but alo when 'tis collected from a dead Viper, and even uch an one that hath been dead many days, provided it be made to pas into a wound, and remain there. Moreover, I added, that this ame liquor, when taken down into the tomach, is not deadly, no not o much as noxious. And this was my opinion, which hath been confirm'd to me by innumerable Experiments, made with the greatet exactnes I could employ.

But the Authors of the Book of the New Experiments do reolutely write, That that above mention'd Liquor is not poionous, but a meer and a mot innocent Saliva or Spitle. Thence they go on to affirm for an undoubted and experimented Truth, that the Viper hath no part of her body, neither limb nor humor, able to poion; and that all her poion conits in the ole imagination of the Viper, irritated and made angry by the Idea of vengeance, which
he hath conceived in her head; by the means whereof the pirits being put into a violent motion, are darted through the Nerves, and at times through the Fibres of the cavities of the Teeth, by which cavities thoe pirits are carried to infect the blood of the animal, by the opening made with the biting teeth. In hort, they conclude, that if a Viper be not angry, and have not that vindicative imagination, her bitings do never poion, but are very innocent, cauing no michief at all to him, in whom they are made. For thee are their words;

Pag. 36. in the Englih Verion, Thee coniderations, upported by many Experiments made by Us, and to be related hereafter, have induced me to call thee GlandsSalival, and to acribe to them the very ource of that yellow liquor, which hath been o much decried, and withal o little known; and it nothing ele, but a pure and a very innocent Spitle. I hope that thoe who hall take the pains of examining after me, thee Glands, and this Juyce of the Gums, will not tick to give me their uffrages.

Item p. 105. 106. But not to tay upon principles o lightly etablihed, and ill maintain'd, for amuch as we have on our ide a
great number of Experiments, upon which we are grounded: We ay, that this Juice is nothing but a pure and plain Saliva, of which we have already oberved the ue; and that this Juice contributes nothing to the venomounes of the Biting, ince being tated and wallowed (as we have often experimented) it doth no hurt to man or beat; and ince alo, being put upon open wounds, and upon inciions made in the fleh, the ame being rub'd therewith, and mingled with the blood, it annoys nothing at all; notwithtanding the judgment of a Peron very intelligent, and particularly in this ubject of Vipers, who aures to have made a great number of Experiments, which being contrary to ours, the great opinion we have of the abilities and the incerity of that famous man, hath obliged us to employ the more care and exactnes, and to confirm our elves by a very great number of Experiments, which have alwayes been found alike in the truth we here aert, and of which we hall make evident and irrefragable proof.

Item p. cog. We conclude therefore, that the imagination of the Viper, irritated by the ideaof revenge, which he had framed to her elf, gives a certain motion to the pirits, which cannot be expreed, and puhes them violently,
through the Nerves and their Fibres, to the cavity of the teeth as into a funnel, and that from thence they are conveyed into the blood of the animal by the opening, which they have made, there to produce all thoe effects, of which we endeavour to give a reaon.

Item pag. III. However this be, we mut herein agree, that this irritation in the fanie or in the pirits of the Viper, is the main caue of the activity and piercingnes of its venom, and that without it the biting would not produce uch urpriing effects, as thoe are, of which we have related o many examples.

Item pag. 138. Thee Experiments will prove on the one hand, that the yellow liquor contributes nothing to the poyon; and on the other, that thee incened pirits, aited by the openings, which the great teeth had made for them, are the ole and true caue thereof.

Thee entiments they confirm by ome Experiments, all which conit in this, that they had drop't a quantity of that yellow liquor into the wounds of a Pigeon, a Dog, and ome Pullets, which yet dyed not of it; and that having caued a Pigeon to be bitten by a Viper not enraged, the animal received thence no hurt at all. For they
ay pag. 115. We alo made a trial upon a Pigeon, which we wounded under the wing and in the Leg in the ame moment of time; and we let into each wound ome of this yellow liquor, which jut afore we had drawn from the gums of two enraged Vipers; then we rejoyned the skin well, to encloe the aid liquor, and we bound both wounds over with a band, that nothing might run out. We can aure, that the Pigeon felt not any inconvenience from it, and that we even found upon the wound, made in the Leg, a coagulated drop of the juice, round, and of the ame colour as we had put it there, and the blood of the wound dryed, and that, oon after, both wounds were dried up, and healed of themelves.

Pag. 116. We alo made the like Experiment upon a Cat, which we purpoely wounded in the Leg, but he received no harm at all by it: We have alo often experimented it on Pullets, and other Pigeons, but alwayes with the like ucces, and without any offence to the Animals.

Ibid. The ame Trial hath been thrice made at three everal times, and even twice in one day upon a Dog, whom we had wounded on purpoe towards the bottom of the Ear, where he could not lick his wound; and no michief at all followed upon it.

Ibid. We cannot but add here an Experiment of the mortal effect of the Enraged Spirits, without any intervention of the yellow liquor. We made a Viper everal times to bite upon a lice of bread, by preing every time its jaws againt the bread; and we did this o often, that not only that juice was altogether exhauted, but the blood began to come out of the Veicles. At the ame time we vexed the Viper, and made her bite a Pigeon in the mot flehy part; and we oberv'd that indeed the effects of the venom of the biting were not o quick, the Pigeon not dying but an hour and an half after it had been bitten; but then we found alo, that the teeth of the Viper were in a manner covered with the crums of the bread, from the force of her having bitten at it, and that that had hindred them from making a deep entrance; and that having half top't up the pores of the teeth, a good part of the angred Spirits could not come forth; o that the death of the Pigeon could not follow o fat, though yet it hapned without any mixture of the juice, which had been altogether emptied.

Pag. 138. The wound made by a Viper not vexed, whoe Jaws were held in, and whoe teeth were at the ame time thrut into
the body of a Pigeon, which alo was accompanied with tore of the yellow juice, and yet not attended with any ill accident.

To thee Experiments I have nothing ele to oppoe, but thoe very many ones, that were made by me in the year 1664. and recited in the above-mentioned Obervations of mine about Vipers, and thoe alo that I hall recite hereafter, made likewie by my elf, not with a deire to confirm the firt, but indeed to dicover the Truth. And, that I may not be put often to repeat ome things, I hall premie ome General Obervations, made by me at the time when I dealt in Vipers.

1. A viper more eaily kills a Pigeon, a Pullet, a Turky-cock, a Squirrel, a Dormoue, and generally all mall Birds and Animals, than a great Animal, as a Sheep, a Deer, a Hore, a Bull; yea thee greater ones and thoe that are of an hard skin, very often a Viper kills not at all.

2. According to the bignes of the Animal bitten, and according to the place where the Viper biteth, death follows ooner or later; epecially according as the place wounded is a clear texture, or thick et with veins and arteries; or thoe veins and arteries are very mall or big.
3. If from the wound of a Viper much blood iueth, it ometimes happens, that the Animal nor only dyeth not, but does not o much as feel any great inconvenience.

4. It doth alo not eldom fall out, that an Animal bitten by a Viper uffers grievous Symptoms from the poyon, which bring it near death, but yet kill it not; but the creature without any help of Phyick and by the ole work of nature recovers.

5. Thoe Animals that are bitten of a Viper dye a little ooner, than thoe, into the wounds of which hath been on purpoe conveyed that yellow liquor, which by art hath been fetch't out of the baggs of the teeth of that Viper.

6. 'Tis neceary, that great dexterity be ued in making the aid liquor to penetrate into the wound; becaue, if the wound be narrow, it pierces difficultly; if large, it cannot be otherwie but it will bleed, and with that blood the aid liquor will turn back, and o the poion come out again.

I had then provided a good number of Vipers which I caued to be brought me cut
of the Kingdome of Naples and having in this moneth of May, 1670 wounded ten Pigeons of the bigger ort in the thighs, I put into them ome of the yellow liquor frehly taken out of the mouth of the live Vipers; and all thee Pigeons, ome within the pace of one hour, ome in half an hour, and ome in two hours, died. This Experiment I repeated upon ten Chickens, likewie wounded in their thighs, with the ame event that had befallen the Pigeons.

Then I cut off the heads of twelf Vipers, and all the heads being cut off, and the Vipers quite dead, I thence extracted the poyon, and caued them to be put into the wounds of eight Turtle-doves, all which died in the pace of half an hour.

In the month of June, having killed many other Vipers, and gather'd out of the bags of their teeth and their gums all the yellow and vicous Juice that was there, I anointed therewith ome beeom-rods, harpn'd like arrowes, and immediately I pricked with them ten young Pigeons in the more flehy part of their chet, leaving them fixed in the wound; and the Pigeons urvived not above two or three hours. But let it hould be doubted; whether thee Pigeons died not
of the wound it elf, enraged by the punctures of thoe rods, I made a trial upon four other Pigeons with rods not infected with that poyonous liquor; but none of them dyed, though the wounds became purulent.
I alo took eight heads of Vipers, cut off ix hours before, and, the Vipers being quite dead, I caued eight Turtle-doves to be bitten by them in the thigh, and not one of them ecaped.

Moreover I made the heads of fifteen Vipers to be cut off: and put them into a glas-veel well cover'd, having laid them upon one another, that o they might remain moit. Four dayes after, I truck with thoe heads five young Cocks, and five great Pigeons in the thigh, and they all after a little while died. The like fell out with other Viper-heads, which having been killed ix dayes before, had in all likely hood lot all choller and thoughts of revenge. And to prevent all Objections that might be raied on this occaion, I hall not omit to relate to you, that about the beginning of Augut when two of my Vipers, that alone were left me in a box, died of themelves of icknes, I caued two Turtle-doves to be truck
by them, which alo, like the former, dyed in les than an hours time.

But I may go further. I had collected in a glas all the poionous liquor of the heads of two hundred and fifty Vipers, to make various Experiments therewith upon occaion. But being by much buines hindred, I delayed to accomplih my deign: Whence that liquor turn't firt into a glew, colour'd like amber; then in 30 dayes it became altogether dry and friable, o that it could eaily be reduced to powder. Being pulveried, I had a mind to try, whether that powder, let into a wound, did keep the force of poyoning; and I found that really it did o, all thoe Pullets, Pigeons, and Turtle-doves, into the wounds of which I had put ome thereof, dying of it in a little while.

Having made this Experiment, I began to doubt, whether that poyon of the arrowes of the King of Macasar in the Iland of Celebes, which commonly are called the arrowes of Bantam in Java Major, were not the poyon extracted out of the mouth of ome Viper, or of ome other Viper-like erpent, and perhaps of a more maligne nature becaue of the diverity of the Climate.
I am not much avere from believing this to be o; and it may be confirmed by what I have read in Pliny, viz. That the Scythians did infect their Arrows with a Viperin poion. His words are, Scythae agittas tingunt Viperinâ anie & humano anguine: irremediabile id celus mortem illicò levi tactu aert. And this was perhaps extracted by Pliny out of Aritotle, who in h • s Book, intitul'd
< in non-Latin alphabet > , oon after decribeth the proces of preparing it, which I dare not affirm to be the true one, or to requi • e o many circumtances and cautions. And who knows, whether the Arrows of Hercules, of which the Fables alledge that they were imbued with the blood of an Hydra, were not infected with this poion of Vipers? So 'tis believed by Diodorus Siculus, when he aith, < in non-Latin alphabet > . And Ovid gives the name of Viper to the Hydra, when in his ninth Book of Metamorph. he aith; Pars quota Lerneae erpens erit unus Echiánae. And afterwards;
—Capit incius heros,
Induitur que humeris Lerneae virus Fchidnae.
To which may be added, that Philoctetes, the Heir of the Bow and Arrows of Hercules, being gon in the Grecian Navy to the Trojan
War, and having unawares wounded himelf (as Servius Grammaticus relates, l. 3. Aeneid) with one of his Arrows in the foot; was left among the Grecians in the Ile of Stalimene, by reaon of the violence of the pain, and the intolerable tench of the wound. Whence Sophocles, alluding, it eems, to the kind of poion, in a Poetical way and phrae relateth, that Philoctetes was left in that Ile, becaue he had been bitten by a Viper. His words are;

O Son of Achilles, I am he, whom thou mayt have heard to be the poesor of the Herculean Arrows, the Son of Paean Philoctetes: whom the two Armies and the King of the Ile of Cephalenehamefully left lying here, pining away by a cruel dieae, truck by the fierce bite of a murthering Viper.

And Cicero himelf in his econd Book of the Tuculan Quetions, and in his Book De Fato, and many other Writers do follow this opinion, viz, That Philoctetes was bitten by
a Viper. And poibly all of them had an eye not only to this place of Sophocles, but alo to what Homer aid before, in his ixteenth Book of Iliads.

And though againt this conjecture it may be aid, that the poiion of Vipers is inconiderable in repect of what Poets do write of the Arrows of Hercules, which by them are aid not only to have the force of killing without fail, whether the wound be mall or great, as happen'd to the Centaure Chiron and to Neus; but alo that the blood of their wounds was become o petiferous as to infect any live body whatoever, touched thereby, and that with uch violence, as to make the fleh fall off from the bones: which, they add, was experimented by Hercules to his great michief, when his Shirt was tinged with the blood of Nesus; whence Ovid aith,
Victa malis potquam et patientia, reppulit aras
Implevit que uis nemoroam vocibus Oeten;
Nec mora, letiferam conatur cindere vetem;
Qua trahitur, trahit illa cutim (faedumque relatu)
Aut haret membris, frutra tentata revelli,
Aut laceros artus & grandia detegit oa:
This is a Poetical Fable; whence, I am apt
to believe, is raied that relation concerning the Arrows of Macaar, of which 'tis aid, that they kill one in that very moment he receiveth the lightet wound thereby, and that alo in the pace of half an hour the fleh of the killed peron becomes o putriied, that it falls off from the bones in many pieces, whence do exhale uch virulent teams, that if they light upon any ordinary and not envenomed wound, they mortally infect it, and without fail kill the Patient.

I do here affirm, that I have made many tryal's with thoe Arrows of the Indians; but have not found them in Tucany of o fierce and malignant a nature, as hath been related. The Dogs I wounded with them, dyed ome of them in ix, others in even, others in twelve, others in twenty four hours. And their fleh was not putriied, nor fallen in pieces, nor did their blood or exhaled teams at all kill other wounded Animals. But I have often oberved, that, if one intends to ki • l with thee Arrows, it is not enough to make a imple inciion of the fleh, but he mut by art make them tick a while in the wound (which is like to what happens in putting into wounds the powder of the dryed yellow liquor of Vipers:) Whence it is that thoe Savages make of Wood the harp
ends of thoe Arrows, imbue them with poion, and then joyne them to the Arrow tick in uch a manner, that thoe ends ever remain in the wound, whether the Arrow do break or be drawn out; as came to pas in the Siege of Jerualem to thoe Heroes of Flandres, Godofred and Robert, of whom that great Florentin Poet thus ingeth:
Sopingeva il monton, quando è percoo
Al Sig. de Fiaminghi il lato manco,
Si che travia s' allenta, è vuol poi trarne
Lo trale, e reta il ferro entro la carne:
That is, The Engine dicharged the left ide of the Flandrian Princes was o truck, that they were thrut out of their way, and when they would draw out the Arrow, the Iron tuck within their fleh.

It is therefore neceary, that the Arrows do tick for ome time in the wound, if they hall kill: Whence I undertand not, how the vulgar comes to fany, that the Blades of Swords may be envenomed. I do well remember, that with the yellow liquor of Vipers, and with other things eteemed venomous, I have ometimes lightly tinged Lancets for letting of blood, and with them have cut the vein of ome Animal or other, but death hath not followed upon it. Let upecting
men rather beware of the Tents of Chirurgions; for 'tis too hard to caue death by poion'd Lancets or other uch Iron intruments. Hence it eems to me to avor of the fable (though the cae be different) that Pariatis the old Queen of the Perians, did poion her Daughter-in-law by the hands of her Carver, poioning the one ide of the Knife, and therewith cutting aunder a Fowl, of which he gave to the young Queen to eat that part, which the poioned ide of the Knife had envenomed, eating the other part himelf.

I could never ee the truth of what is related of poions killing by a meer and momentaneous contact, or by vicinity alone; as that Stirrups, Sadles, and Benches have been poioned, and thereby proved mortal. Let him believe it that will; I cannot. And what a certain modern Writer relateth for a great truth, concerning a prodigious accident hapned by a kind of Serpents bred in the Indies, I mut leave to himelf, who aith,After I have poken of thee Serpents, I preume it will not be unacceptable to give an account of the trange effect they produce. If perchance it happen, that they pas over a cloath or hirt dryed in the Sun, there is wont to be bred in the Kidneys of thoe that ue this cloath, a certain
kind of Serpents, which little by little growing up do encompas the whole body, and when their tayl reaches their head, to conjoyn the circle, then death is unevitable: Wherefore, to avoyd this michief, they kill them with Razors and Lancets, to prevent their growth.

You have found above mentioned three perons, wounded by the Arrows of Hercules, namely Chiron, Neus, and Philoctetes. The two firt dyed uddenly; the third, after a long icknes ecaped. If the caufes of this difference were to be given (whether it be an Hitory or a Fable) I hould ay, that Neus and Chiron dyed, becaue they were wounded whilt Hercules was yet living, by Arrows frehly envenomed; beides that Neus was pierced through his heart, as Ovid hath it,
Jámque tenens ripam mios cùm tolleret artus,
Conjugis agnovit vocem, Neóque paranti
Fallere depoitum; quò te fiducia, clamat,
Vana pedum violente rapit? Tibi, Nee biformis
Dicimus, exaudi, nec res intercipe notras.
Si te nulla mei reverentia movit; at orbes
Concubitus vetitos poterant inhibere paterni.
Haud tamen effugies, quamvis ope fidis equinâ,
Vulnere, non pedibus, te conequar. Ultima dicta
Re probat, & miâ fugientia terga fagittâ
Trajicit; extabat ferrum de pectore aduncum:
Quod imul evulum et, anguis per utrumque foramen
Emicuit, mitus Lernaei tabe veneni.
But Philoctetes was wounded long after the death of Hercules; whence 'tis credible, that thoe Arrows had lot much of their poionous force, even as the powder of the yellow liquor looeth of its force, and the Arrows of Macaer by length of time grow languid; which though they poion and kill if one be wounded therewith, yet do they no hurt at all, if their poion be wallow'd and taken into the tomach. Which Experiment I have tryed upon two Doggs, to whom I gave to wallow two pieces of fleh covered with the powder of the crapings of uch Arrows; as alo upon everal Chickens, to whom I gave the water to drink, wherein thoe havings had been a long time infued.

But, to return after this long digreion to the main thing; you may by the above related and often repeated Experiments, ee, that the po • on of the Italian Viper conits not in an imaginary idea of anger raied to revenge, but rather in that yellow liquor,
which is voided out of the bags of the bigger teeth of Vipers; which juyce if it chance to be pilled in the mouth and upon the Pallat of thoe animals is able to envenoin the pittle which moitens their throat.

I hould think it very well worth while for thoe learned Authors of the book of the New Experiments, that they would pleae to make their Experiments anew. And if they hall find them conform to thoe they have already publihed, and really contrary to mine, then we may unanimouly conclude, that we have lighted upon a truth hitherto unknown; which is, That the Poion of the French Vipers conits in an imaginary Idea of a revengeful anger; but that of the Italian ones hath its eat in that yellow liquor, o often mentioned by me. But if on the other ide, the French Experiments hould not hold, then it may be affirmed, that the French as well as the Italian Vipers are of one and the ame nature; and have the ame kind of poion.

Wherefore if in Italy the Viper in poion certainly lodges in that yellow liquor, it will be no untruth in me to affirm, that if by biting, a Viper hould have lot all that juyce reiding in thoe bags, and that alo which may be furniht by the neighbouring parts, it
will, I ay, be no untruth in me to affirm, that the ubequent bitings will not be mortal: which is the thing I have thee many years aerted, and do till aert, although the aboveaid Authors deny it, giving out that one only Viper, being vexed and well'd with choller, is able to kill as many animals as she bites; they truting to one Experiment, in which they ay there died five young Pidgeons by the biting of one only Viper. We hope (ay they, p. 137.) that among the many Experiments thoe of the five Pidgeons, bitten one after another, by one and the fame viper exaperated every time, and of which the lat bitten died firt of all, when the viper was mot vexed, and mot exhauted of its yellow liquor, &c.

I am willing indeed to believe the fact to be true; but for the confirmation of it I wih they had caued many more uch Pidgeons, and many other animals, of different kinds and bignees, to be bitten of the elf ame Viper, which had killed thoe five ones, to ee whether that angry and cholerick poion had an infinite power. For when I examin'd this matter, I choe about the beginning of May a Female Viper, one of the bigget and lutiet, and vexed her to bite ten Chickens one after another, in the right thigh; of which
the firt, econd, and third died almot in an intant; the fourth eemed only to be ick; but the fifth and all the ret did not only not dye, but were not at all ick; and yet every time the Viper did bite, I angred and madded her exceedingly. In the moneth of June I repeated the experiment in five tame Ducks, bitten by one and the ame Viper, which alo immediately after bit three young Turtle-Doves. The firt wounded Duck dyed three hours after; the econd, five hours after; but the ret ecaped. 'Tis true, that the firt wounded of the Turtles dyed, but not the other two. Of twelve Ring-Doves at one time there dyed but four; but the next day of twelve others there dyed ix. Of five Rabbets there dyed three and of three Lambs the two lat lived, the firt of them dying two hours after it had been bitten.

I hould be too tedious, if I hould relate to you all the other experiments: Wherefore I hall go on to add, that having written in my Obervations, that that yellow liquor was not conveyed to the bags of the teeth from the bladder of gall, I did ugget, whether it might not be digorged there by certain everalDuctus's, that might be inerted at the head of them: which did appear the more probable, becaue that in all Vipers at the
bottom of thoe veicles I had always found two glanduls, which had not, that I knew, been oberved or decribed by any body. Whereupon the Authors of the New Experimentsdo affirm, that they could never ee uch Glanduls as I had named; but that intead of them they had found two others, which they call Salival, thus by them decribed,p. 31, 32. I believed at firt, following Signor Redi, that there might be Salival veels in Vipers, as there have been lately found in Man and divers other Animals; o that after many re-earches made with ufficient attention and patience, in many Vipers heads I dicovered at length uch Glands, proper to forme this juyce, and to convey it to the Bags; and after I was well perwaded of it my elf, I hewed them to divers of thoe knowing Phyitians, that had met at my houe the lat year. Thee perons had a mind to ee them with their own eyes; and after I had well examined the parts which I hewed them, they not only found them true, but they alo aw there a greater number of maller veels then had appear'd to me, of which ome that are Arteries and Veins pas above the Glands, and others that are Lympheducts run below; o that they judged, that I could confidently aert and decribe thee Glands which I call Salival, and which they had acknowledged together with
me; though Signor Redi durt not peak poitively of them, becaue he had not dicovered them; neither had they been decribed by any Author of their knowledge, nor by any one of mine.

And pag. 35. As to the mall Glands, whichSignor Redi hath oberved at the bottom of the Veicles that contain this juyce, I can ay, that I have with great care and diligence earched after them, and that 'tis true, I have there found the appearances of Glands, but having opened them, I aw nothing in them but mall teeth that were fatned there, without finding any thing of a Glandular nature there, nor that did in the leat approach to the hape, ubtance, or qualities of the Glands which I have been decribing,&c.

I do not at all wonder that thoe Writers have not found thoe Glanduls I named, I eeing they went about to earch them within the Veicles of the teeth, and at the bottom of them: Whereas I never aid that they were to be found within them, I aid they were to be found Sotto'l fondo (under the bottom) of thoe bags, and in good Tucan language, tis another thing to ay nel fondo, (in or at the bottom) another Sotto'l fondo (under the bottom.) And therefore when they • ought them where they are to be met with, they eaily
found them, and they are the ame which they decribe, neither are there any other coniderable glanduls to be dicovered in the heads of Vipers. Nor could I at all write that thoe Glanduls lay in the bottom of the Veicles, if I was of opinion that the yellow liquor did run into them after it had paed through the Salival Conduits, which yet I imagined might have their origin from, or connexion with thoe two Glanduls een by me, and therefore mut needs be in a cituation a little ditant from the Veicles, and not in the bottom of them. Now whether thee Glanduls have this office and this ue, I intend not now to peak of, let it be what it will, 'tis too inconiderable a matter to make any more words of it.

I confes, that the dangerous experiments which Vipers have, made them o dipleaing to me, and even o odious, that I reolved not at all to meddle any more with them; but that I was tempted thereto by a great deire I had experimentally to learn, whether the volatil Salt of Vipers, Chymically prepared, were endowed with that preent and infallible vertue of curing the bitings of Vipers, as the aid Writers affirm. For my Genius keeps me from much truting to thoe things, that have not been made out to me by Experiment; although I do not preently reject
them as fale before Experiment, but rather being deirous to know whether they be true, I put them to tryal: But neither do I acquiece in one or a few experiments, but I love to ee more and more, being ever apprehenive let I hould be deceived; as it often hath happen'd to me, when I have been ready to confide in one haty experiment. And to ay truth in the moneth of June there wanted not much but that I had impoed upon my elf in the tryal of an experiment, which I am going to relate to you, and which done I hall eae you of further trouble.

Having read them in the Book of the New Experiments, that the Head of a Viper, being eaten of an animal, bitten by another Viper, did certainly cure the wound; and the thing being by me looked upon as very ueful, excellent, and admirable, I had an eager deire to try it my elf, that I might peak of it with more confidence, although thoe learned men had made thee two following experiments of it, viz. pag. 120. We had alo a deire to find whether a Viper being eaten by an animal, which he had bitten before, would be cured of that biting. We therefore caued to be lightly broiled the head of a Viper, which had on it a part of the neck, newly ever'd from the body; and we caued a Dog to be thrice bitten at the ear, by a well
enraged Viper, in uch a manner that the blood came out at the three pricked places. We oon cat before him the head and neck; broiled, and yet hot. The Dog, that was hungry, and felt not o oon the effects of the bitings, immediately eized on the head, bruied it between his teeth, and wallowed it down. After which we tay'd a pretty while to ee, whether the three bitings would prevail over the devour'd head and neck but the Dog was free, except ome blewnes and a little Tumour he had at the places bitten, but which little by little vaniht in three or four days. We made alo a Dog to be bitten three times in the ame place, and without broiling the head of the ame Viper that had bit him, we cat it before him, hoping that he would eat it, becaue he had not eaten any thing for many hours before; but the Dog would not touch it. Upon that we bruied and tamped that head in a mortar, and o cram'd it down the Dogs throat, rubbing alo the bitten places with the blood of the ame Viper; which done, we expected the ucces, which was that this head, raw and bruied, and if you will, aited by the blood of the Viper, being applied to the part bitten, had produced the ame effects with the former, which had been lightly broiled; in regard that this Dog was afe, excepting thoe inconveniencies the former uffer'd, and was after that as ound as if he had never been bitten.
If thee two Experiments had been made before that Gentleman, above dicours'd of, was bitten by a Viper, we hould have been in much les anxiety for his preervation.

And a little before (pag. 119.) they had aid: We have tryed, that having caued to be bitten at the thicket place of the ear, by a ufficiently vexed Viper, a young Cat, very lean, that had but jut before eaten the Eggs, the Matrix, and all the Guts of a Viper; the biting had almot no effect, and there appeared nothing but a very little welling, and a very inconiderable lividnes in the part bitten.

And pag. 154. It is very certain, that the Head of a Viper, broiled and wallowed, healeth the biting of that Animal. The Heart and the Liver may do the ame. Reaon and Experience have confirm'd it; and therefore in an urgent occaion thee parts may be very beneficially employed.

And pag. 156. We believe, that the Liver wallowed is capable to heal the biting of a Viper, like the heart, fleh and other parts, of which we have poken; and that it may much facilitate the delivery of Women with Child, as doth the Liver of Eeles.

Hereupon I reolved to imitate thoe Gentlemen, and having given a Vipers head half boiled to a chain'd young Dog, I caued him
immediately to be bitten by an other Viper in the right ear, but the Dog dyed not, nor did he appear to me to have any other inconvenience than that he tood as 'twere amazed, and looking grim, and melancholly, for four or five hours pace. I oon reiterated the ame Experiment upon another Dog, which having been forced to wallow the head of a Viper, raw and bruied in a Mortar, gave no ign of any great poion, and had very little and almot no ill enuing. Whence I was ready to reckon this Experiment among things proved and true, when a doubt coming into my mind, obliged me to caue two other young Dogs to be bitten in their ears, who although they had not eaten the counter-poion of a Vipers head, yet dyed not. Whence the upicion being increaed in me, I caued to be brought me the raw head of a Viper, and crammed it into the throat of a young Pullet, and then had its left thigh bitten by a Viper; whereupon it preently fell to the ground, and in a little more then the eight part of an hour died. Whence the upicion growing till greater, about ten a clock in the morning I made a Capon to eat two raw heads of Vipers, and afterwards about twelve a clock I made him wallow two others, and without loing any time I caued him to be once
bitten by a Viper in the thigh, and the Capon immediately dyed, without finding any good in the four wallow'd heads. The next day I prepared for two young Dogs a dih of Viper-heads parboiled, but they would not eat them, and we were forced to cramm them down: Soon after, the leer of the two Dogs was bitten in the thigh near the groin, and the bigger in the tongue; and they both dyed. And in the like manner dyed eight Chickens, two Kitlings, two young Hares, and ix Turtle-Doves, likewie bitten by Vipers, and Phyiqued not only by their heads, both raw and boiled, but alo having their wounds wahed with the Viper-blood. And I remember, that I caued thoe 6 Turtle-Doves to be bitten not by the heads of live Vipers, but by thoe of dead ones, and uch as had dyed two days before. Moreover, I continued for three days ucceively to cram two uch other Doves with Viper-leh, and gave them no other drink then the broth of that leh; and yet they could not ecape death, being bitten by a Viper.

Whence I am inclined to believe, that in Tucany the leh of Vipers is no help or remedy, at leat no coniderable one, to Animals bitten by Vipers. Mean while I refer my elf to the Learning, Experience, and Authority
of thoe noble perons, to whom I do mot willingly ubmit this or any other opinion of mine, and with whom I would never entertain a controverie. For I hould apprehend let it might befall me, what Marcus Tullius was wont to ay of Cato, viz. That it was not les troubleome to him to anwer to the authority of Cato, then to his tronget arguments.

For the ret, I earnetly intreat you, Sirs, that you would pardon the rudenes of this my Letter, ufficiently appearing to have been written by a peron full of buines, rather then enjoying leiure; and that you would pleae only to regard the naked truth, which without any paion I did undertake to relate.

A CONTINUATION Of the NEW EXPERIMENTS CONCERNING VIPERS: TOGETHER With a Dicoure touching their Poyon: By way of Reply, to a Letter written by Signor FRANCESCO REDI, to Meieurs BOURDELOT and MORUS; Printed at Florence, 1670.
By MOYSE CHARAS. Englih'd out of French.
LONDON,Printed by T. R. for John Martyn Printer to the Royal Society, at the Bell in S. Pauls Churchyard, 1673.

div.head: A CONTINUATION Of the NEW EXPERIMENTS CONCERNING VIPERS.
Finiht in the Pres at Paris, Augut 4. 1671.
div.p:
I Believed, I had ufficiently etablih'd my opinion touching the Poion of Vipers by abundance of Experiments, upported by Reaons, heretofore made publick: But there hath ince appear'd at Paris a Letter of Signor Redi, in which he oppoes my entiments: And he being a peron, whoe merit hath acquir'd him a great reputation among the Learned, that Letter of his hath not been without making ome impreion in the minds of many, and in ome even of thoe, that had relih'd my opinion, in
favour of which they eem'd to have already declared themelves.

I might indeed have defended my elf as to that which is againt me in that Letter, oon after it appear'd; having reaons trong and numerous enough to maintain and jutifie all I had advanced in my writing: But I thought it better to deferr it till Spring, to the end that after I hould have made New Experiments, and the more aur'd my elf of all, I might, by a renew'd knowledge of the truth, afterwards the better perwade the publick thereof. It will therefore appear by this Sequel of Experiments, here et down, that I am o far from changing my Opinion, that I have reaon to be more trongly than ever confirmed in what I embraced at firt.

I do herewith incerely declare, that when I publihed my book, my chief aim was, faithfully to relate all the truths I had dicover'd, and not to offend Signor Redi, whom I exceedingly eteem and honour for his rare Talents, and whoe friendhip I hope to have a hare in; o far was I from pretending to do any thing that might make him write againt my Book, or from fore-eeing that ever I hould have occaion to labour to defend my elf againt him: Which yet I ince found otherwie, by the Letter he hath written
againt me, and even without honoring me with a Copy of it, wherewith he hath gratified many perons at Paris and elewhere, even after I had had the advantage of ome Letterary Commerce with him, as I might eaily jutifie.

I can beides protet, that when I reolved to contradict certain points of his firt Letter, it was in a manner againt my will, and becaue I could not at all dipene with it, except I would have baffled my enes, and that light I aw my elf, together with a great number of witnees. I can alo aure, that I hould now be very ready to un-ay what I have affirm'd upon this ubject, and to agree with him, if I were not altogether perwaded of the contrary in the main things he hath written againt my Sentiments.

After thee Protetations, being well aured as well by Reaon, as by many new Experiments newly made, that I have aerted nothing but what is true; I found my elf indipenably obliged to maintain it, and to render a good office to the publick, by endeavouring to hew that 'tis very difficult reaonably to oppoe any thing to the contrary.

The difference between Signor Redi and me conits chiefly in this, That he Pretends, the Jellow Liquor contain'd in the Veicles
of the Gums of Vipers, to be the only and true eat of their Poion; That this juyce is not venomous when taken at the mouth, but that it is o when let into the wounds made by a Viper whilt he is alive, and even in thoe, which he may be forced to make everal days after he is dead, provided that yellow liquor do intervene; That the ame liquor drawn from a live Viper, as well as that of a dead one, is always venomous if let into wounds, and mingled with the blood of the Animal wounded, whether it be ued when liquid, or after it is dryed and reduced to powder; and that it generally kills all kind of Animals into the wounds of which it hall have been intromitted.

But I, who of all thee points can admit of none but that of the innocence of the yellow liquor when taken at the mouth, and oppoing my elf to all the ret; do ay, That the Poion of a Viper is no where but in her enraged Spirits; that the yellow juyce as well of a live Viper, and even a vexed one, as of one that is either newly dead, or hath been o for everal days, contains in it no poion at all, neither in the biting, nor taken inwardly, nor put into wounds, nor mingled with the blood, nor any other way wherein it may be ued; that it kills nor infects any kind of animals;
and that it is nothing but a meer and innocent Saliva.

The quetion mut principally be decided by matter of Fact; though it may alo be cleared by very pertinent reaons. I am far from accuing Signor Reds of unfaithfules in his Experiments; though they were not made in publick as mine, and that ome thing might be aid as to the formalities of the biting, and the uing of the yellow liquor: His reputation is too well grounded to be blamed; and this is the conideration which troubles me mot. Mean time I ee the contrary to what he hath advanced againt my Book; and the truths which I there oppoe are o clearly een in my Experiments firt and lat, as well in thoe I have made only in the preence of ome curious perons, as in thoe I have lately made in publick, and before a great number of Phyitians and other perons very intelligent in thee matters. So that I can no •
ought any longer to hide thoe truths, which are the chief inducement of writing this dicoure.

We need not wonder that Signor Redi, having made all his Experiments by order and at the expence of o great a Prince, who is as curious as he is Munificent, had Vipers and all orts of Animals in far greater number than
I had; I, who did all from my elf, at my own charges, and with a meer deire to dicern truth from falhood. Nor do I think, I was obliged to multiply expences when the truth was found ufficiently clear'd up, and all the by-tanders acknowledged, that I had made ufficient tryals for every Experiment. For ince he hath contented himelf with having made ome of the yellow liquor to be wallowed by one only Man, one only Duck, one only Kid, thence to know and to aure himelf of its innocence when wallow'd, without making a greater number of Experiments; He mut not blame me for having candidly bounded my curioity, after I had in divers things made many more Experiments, then he mentions he hath made upon this ubject; as appears by what he writeth p. 17, & 18. of his firt Letter. I find therefore, that he hath no great caue to complain of me (as he doth, under the name of thoe Illutrious Authors, to whom he acribes my Book in his Letter) for not having vouchafed to make Experiments enow to confirm the truth of the Obervations about Vipers, contain'd in his firt Letter of 1664. He had not, I ay, great caue to peak of it after uch a manner, ince I did do o but in imitation of him, and becaue he had in the ame Letter advanced and aured
particulars, which required not I hould make more tryals then thoe I have decribed in my Book: Although I can aure to have made more then I have recited. He knows very well, that about the end of pag. 23. of his firt Letter he ued thee words.

Equel veleno hizza tutto fuora, e non al primo, almeno al econdo moro; i che il terzo (epiù volte l'ho eperimentato) non è velenoo:That is, And that poion iues all out, if not at the firt, at leat at the econd biting; o that the third (which I have often experimented)is not venomous.

And if, becaue of the repect I bear to the writings of a peron of o high a reputation, I thought among divers other Experiments, that having made one and the ame Viper, every time vexed, to bite five everal Pigeons, which all died, and even the lat of them ooner then the ret, I might top there; I think Signor Redi hath nothing to reproach me with. He had aured in his firt Letter, and aures the ame in his latter, That all the poion did lodge in the yellow liquor, and that this poion was all exhauted if not at the firt, yet at leat at the econd biting, and that he had often experimented that the third was no more venomous: So that, if I was perwaded, that all the yellow Liquor mut be
come out by the econd biting made upon the econd Pigeon, and if, after that, I have een dye three other Pigeons by the freh bitings of the ame Viper that had bitten the two firt; I do not think that Sign. Redi hath right to accue me for not having done enough: He might rather have done me that jutice as to acknowledge, that I had done more then enough to maintain my Reflexions, and that I was obliged from that time to eek the poion elewhere then in the yellow liquor, in regard it did no longer intervene, according to him, in the three lat bitings, and that the three lat Pigeons were as oon, yea ooner, dead then the two firt, of the death of which he could charge the yellow liquor. If I could not find, no more then Sign. Redi, in all the body of the Viper, any other viible or palpable part that was venomous, and that might jutly be declared to be the eat of the poion, and the true caue of the death which enued upon the three lat bitings; he mut not wonder, if I have ought and found it in the vexed Spirits, and if I have grounded my elf upon the bet evidence, I could get from Experiments and Reaon.

But ince the chief motive of my tryals hath been the deire of exactly knowing the Truth concerning thoe matters; having een that
Sign. Redi, pag. 31. of his lat Letter hath deired I would make new experiments after his Objections againt me: To be the more aured of all, I have been willing to give him that atisfaction, in giving it to my elf. For, in the moneth of May lat, in the Chymical Laboratory of the Royal Garden, in the preence of two or three hundred by tanders, both Phyitians and others, capable to judge of it, and worthy to be credited; from amongt many live Vipers, ent me out of Dauphine, and divers parts of Poitou, I choe a great Femal-Viper, that was luty enough notwithtanding the great way he came, and having open'd her jawes, I very carefully cleared and queezed out of them at everal repetitions, all the yellow liquor contained in the bags of her gums, and that alo which might be diffued about the neighbouring parts, with a fine piece of linnen cloth wound about the handle of a pen knife: Which done, I took the ame Viper with Pincers about hér neck, and angred her in making her to faten her teeth into the end of her tail, and in preing from time to time her neck with thoe Pincers; and immediately after I preented to her five Pigeons and two Pullets one after another, to bite them in the mot flehy part of their Chet, having irritated her every time
of her biting. I purpoely wounded alo ix Pigeons and Pullets in divers places, in the preence of all the company, and let into the wounds ome drops of the yellow liquor, drawn from the Veicles of newly enraged Vipers. I laid both orts a part; and the company parted about an hour after, before which time, five of the Pigeons and Pullets, that had been bitten, were dead, and the two remaining died about an hour after; but the Pigeons and Pullets, which I had wounded, and in whoe wounds I had put in ome of the aid juyce, ailed nothing, but that there appeared ome lividnes, at the place wounded, and uch an one as might have been there from the ole wounding them, and without any concurrence of that liquor. Two days after, I hew'd the company the ame wounded Pullets and the ame Pigeons, which were very well, and had their wounds almot perfectly healed up, only there remain'd a little blewnes about the wounded parts. I would then have wounded the ame animals again in other places, and intromitted freh yellow liquor: ome alo of the by-tanders propoed to let into one of thee creatures ome of this yellow liquor by that way of Transfuion, that hath lately been made in divers parts of Europe, of ome tranger blood
into the veins of men, that o this juyce being mingled with the blood by the ordinary circulation, it might be able to dicover what ever it could do. I readily complied with their motion, whereupon the intromiion of this liquor was attempted upon one of the ame Pigeons that had been wounded two days before. One Phyitian and two Chirurgions did the work one after onother, in making both the inciion and the ligature of the mot dicernable veels of the right wing: But they let the Pigeon looe o much blood, that it dyed oon after. Seeing this, I aid, that the Pigeon dyed only from the los of its blood, and not from the letting in of the yellow liquor; and that it would be neceary, one only Chirurgion of the Company hou'd make a new operation upon another of the ame Animals, that had been wounded 2 days before, and upon whom that yellow Juyce had alo been tryed. The Operation was made accordingly at the ame time upon a Pullet, which did not only ecape again, but was een the next day and the following days by the whole company to be very well; as were alo the other animals that had been wounded again at the ame time, and received of the yellow liquor, though without the way of transfuion. Yet true it is, that one of the
Pigeons, that had been the econd time wounded, was found dead ome time after its being wounded, in a cloe earthen Furnace, very hot, and tanding cloe by uch another, where I then ditilled ome pirit and oyl of Tobacco, and the death of which ought to be imputed to the piercing vapors of this ditillation, or to the exceive heat of the Furnace in which it had been hut up, which was found o hot, that the heat of it could not be endured by ones hand; beides that being cloed, almot no air could enter.

Which being thus paed, yet foramuch as the reputation of Sign. Redi had acquired him much eteem and favour from many perons in Paris, I perceived ome of the company yet inclined to doubt, whether this yellow Juyce were always innocent. Whereupon, having by me 4 Dogs of different bignes, I pres'd thoe that eemed mot to doubt, that they would transfue or caue to be transfued ome of that reputed poionous liquor into all thoe Dogs, or at leat into one or other of them; but how intant oever I was, no body would undertake it. It was alledged, that thoe Animals were too Robut to Succumb under uch an operation, ince the Pullet, that had endur'd it, and twice felt the yellow liquor, had ecaped as well as the
other Animals, that had been wounded again at the ame time with it, and that had alo received into them ome of that liquor. Which obliged me to protet, it was not my fault that it was not experimented a freh, and to pray the company to take the refual of thoe perons for an acknowledgment of the innocence of the yellow liquor.

But not being atisfied herewith, I referred the matter to the next day, and promied to have ready new Animals, of a leer ize than thoe Dogs; the more amply to verifie the innoxiounes of that Juyce by new intromiions thereof into wounds.

I had then prepar'd ix Pigeons, and two Carlings; and engaged a peron whom I knew mot favourable to Signor Redi, to make himelf the inciion, and intromit the yellow liquor as he hould think bet. He made uch wounds as he pleaed, and he did even ever the skin of the fleh round about the wounds he had made, and o far, that I could not hold to tell him miling, he did more than Signor Redi himelf aid in his Letters he had done; and added, Boni ee patoris tondere, non de glubere, A good Shepherd did Sheer, not Flea his Sheep.

The ix latter Pigeons, that had been wounded at the ame time, and received of the yellow liquor, were likewie produced; and they were yet kept five or ix days with the other Pigeons and Pullets that had been twice wounded before; among which was that alo on which the transfuion had been imitated. At lat they were killed, roted, and eaten, in good company, of which were ome of thoe that aw them wounded; and that found them very good and avoury meat.

Amidt all thoe Experiments I omitted not to try, whether the heads of Vipers newly dead, having yet their necks on, with all their yellow liquor, would be able to kill Animals, by making them to be bitten by them. I tryed it upon Pigeons and Pullets, by thruting the teeth into them as deep as I could. I employed alo to the ame purpoe ome whole Vipers, which I had found dead among the live ones in the barrils, and which abounded in the yellow liquor. But this was always without any inconvenience to the Animals bitten, o far was it from killing them.

I here pas by many other Experiments made at my houe, in the preence of everal Phyitians, that did all agree in making out the innocence of the yellow liquor, and in acribing the poionounes to the enraged pirits.

Yet I mut not leave here un-mentioned, what was done by three young Phyitians, who being perwaded of the truth of my Experiments, as well concerning the innocence of the yellow liquor, as that of bitings made without the angred pirits, caued their fingers to be bitten, to trifes, by a dead Viper having yet all her yellow liquor, and that o deep, that the blood of it appeared to all: But they found no other inconvenience by it, but what they might have felt from prickings made by a needle.

I had certainly made a far greater number of Experiments if I had not oberved, that Sign. Redi himelf had already made many for me, and for the maintaining of my Sentiments; and among others that of pag. 26. of his firt Letter of Obervations, where he aith,
Si mori un pollatro moricato, &c. That is,There dyed a Pullet bitten by a Viper, the points of whoe teeth I had cut off; and out of whoe vesicles I had queezed out all that ill juyce that it there.

For, ince by his own confeion, there dyed a Pullet by having been bitten by a Viper, the points of whoe teeth he had deignedly cut off, and all whoe yellow liquor (which he calls the ill juyce, and will have to be the only eat of the poion) he had carefully pres'd out of the veicles of her Gums; He hath no more ground then I, to charge the death of the Pullet upon a liquor, which was there no more, nor upon the points of the teeth, which he had cut off. And he cannot avoid to accue with me the vexed pirits of the Viper, and to fall into my opinion, viz, That the venom of the Viper is not a gros matter, but omething inviible and piritual.

And to hew again, that Signor Redi hath laboured, without being aware of it, to jutifie my Sentiment, and that at the ame time he manifetly contradicts himelf, by detroying in his lat Letter his firt Propoitions, which is, That all the venom of the Viper iues at the firt, or at leat at the econd biting, and that the third is venomous no more, as he aureth to have often experimented; to hew that, I ay, I hall alledge the words of pag. 33, 34, and 35. of his lat Letter, viz.

Su'l principio di maggio celi una vipera, &c. That is, About the beginning of May I choe a Femal-Viper, one of the bigget and lutiet, and
vexed her to bite ten Chickens, one after another, in the right thigh; of which the firt, econd and third died almot in an intant; the fourth eem'd only to be ick; but the fifth and all the ret did not only not dye, but were not at all ick; and yet every time the Viper did bite, I angred and madded her exceedingly. In the moneth of June I repeated the Experiment in five tame Ducks, bitten by one and the ame Viper, which alo immediately after bit three young Turtle-Doves. The firt wounded dyed three hours after; the econd-five hours after; the ret ecaped. 'Tis true, that the firt mention'd of the Turtles dyed, but not the other two. Of twelve Ring-Doves at one time there dyed but four; but the next day of twelve others there dyed ix. Of five Rabbets there dyed three; and of three Lambs the two lat dyed; the firt of them dying two hours after it had been biten.

Thee everal Experiments directly contrary to the firt aertion of Signor Redi, were capable to perplex any other head but
• is. For firt, he hath een, that of ten bullets bitten one after another by one only Viper, the three firt dyed uddenly, and the fourth was omewhat ick; He hath een, that of five Ducks and of three Pigeons, bitten one after another by a ingle Viper, the two firt Ducks dyed, as alo one of the Pigeons, which
had been bitten even after the five Ducks: He alo aw once, that of twelve Pigeons bitten, four dyed; that another time of twelve there ecaped but the moiety; and that of five Rabbets, likewie bitten, there were but two that evaded dying.

I cannot but be amazed, that all thee Experiments have not been able to change his opinion, or at leat to upend it. Nor do I doubt but that the number of Animals that d • ed would have been much greater, if the bitings had been made in other places but the legs. For, beides that they have their bones, nerves, and tendons, that are able to blunt the point of the teeth at the firt biting; they have alo their Mucles, which are very vicous, and therefore fail not to imbue the teeth of the biting Viper, thereby topping in part their Pores, and even hindring them by that v • coity from entring far in the enuing bites, and I likewie doubt not, but that will come to pas more and more in the reiteration of their bitings. Nor do I wonder, that the Ducks did not dye o oon as the Pullets or Pigeons, nor that there dyed les of them; for, beides the reaons jut now alledged, they have their skin, bones, and all parts much harder, and far more difficult to be pierced by the Vipers teeth, than thoe of Pigeons or
Pullets. Now I do not find any part mo • e proper to try divers bitings, then the flehy part of the chet, which hath neither Nerves, nor Tendons, nor bones near, nor that Vicoity found in the Mucles of the legs.

Mean time thee Experiments made by Sign. Redi himelf, mut oblige him, as far as I can judge, to relinquih his firt Aertion: And if he will perit to maintain, that the yellow liquor is the true eat of the poion, he mut needs believe that liquor to be inexhautible, and that always there ucceeds ome freh, in all the bitings of a Viper; or, if he will abandon his opinion, and acribe the poion no more to the yellow liquor, he mut find out ome other ubject to aign it to, except he pleae to take mine, and to lodge it in the irritated pirits; in regard that he cannot find it in the yellow liquor, which is no more there, after the econd biting (as himelf aureth;) and which mut yet more evidently be wanting there, when deignedly he had with care taken it out of the bags of the gums of the Viper that bit the Pullet, and the bite of which was followed by the death of the Animal bitten.

But if Sign. Redi hould now be in an humor to alter his opinion, and to judge the yellow liquor to be neceary in all the bitings of a
Viper (though that be an impoible thing;) his opinion would never be received by diintereed perons, that have een my firt and lat Experiments; among which perons there are ome, even of the mot able, who, having heretofore examin'd the Salival Glanduls upon the decription I gave them of it after I had dicover'd them, did there oberve alo ome mall Lymphatic Veels, more numerous then thoe that had firt appeared to me; and who, having een the lat Letter of Sign. Redi, were willing to upend their Judgment until the making of my new Tryals, which have altogether confirm'd them in my firt opinion.

For, not to peak of this, that in the preence of divers perons, even of the bet quality, at everal times and places, in divers aemblies, & even in the Conferences of the Abbot Bourdelot; I have wallow'd ome of the yellow liquor taken out of the bags of the gums of many live and enraged Vipers, without finding the leat inconvenience from it, no more then the Viper-catcher of Sign. Redi: I can boldly aure all the world, that at no time, in no place, there ever dyed any animal of all thoe I have wounded, or een wounded on purpoe, and into the wounds of which that liquor hath been intromitted, although it had been drawn hot out of the Veicles of
the gums of Vipers exceedingly vexed; o far is it, that the Juyce of dead Vipers was able to annoy any animal. I can alo aure, that never any head of a dead Viper, whether the Animal were who • e, or that head only with its neck, and though it abounded with that yellow liquor, hath done any harm to man or any other Animal, bitten by it.

The yellow liquor, which I wallow'd in one of the conferences of the Abbot Bourdelot, puts me in mind of Letter, which M. Des Tapieres, a very curious, incere and able Apothecary of Bourbon l' Archamband, had written to him, which was there read, and among other things did relate, That in the year 1630. he had taken a Viper, whoe crook'd teeth he had cut, and that he carried her in his boom; and that after two or three days, a fancy taking him to approach her to his face, preing her a little, he bit him in his lip, and thereby caued great pain to him; whereupon he flung her to the ground and in his anger cruht her in pieces; that his lip and face welled; that a Ligature was made upon him; that Treacle was given him, and ome of it applied to the bite; that at the place of the wound there appear'd a little bladder, whence iued two or three drops of liquor of a dark yellow colour, and that
his face remain'd very pale for a moneth.

If my opinion be asked about this Experiment, I declare that there is nothing in it, which I ought not to believe; and I add alo, that there hapn'd nothing in it, which agrees not with the principles by me etablih'd and maintain'd. For, although the great teeth of that Viper had been cut, which might have gone further, and mingled the enraged pirits of the Viper with the blood of M. Tapieres; yet they had not cut the point of the mall teeth, which I hew'd in the ame conference together with the other neighbouring parts in the teath of a live Viper, ent to Monieur Bourdelot by the ame Apothecary that had been bitten: of which mall teeth I have heretofore given the decription and figure, as well as that of the upper and lower Jawes, in which they are fatn'd, as may be een in my Anatomy of Vipers, in the Section of the teeth, and the third Cut of that Pook. For, although thoe little teeth have not the length nor thicknes of the great ones; yet they have the ame hape and the ame matter; for they are bony, crooked, tranparent, and very harp; o that the vexed pirits may pas into them as into mall Funnels, and through their Pores, as they do thorough thoe of the bigger ones: But they cannot go very deep,
becaue their malnes permits them not to carry their openings as far as into the fleh; and all they can doe, is, to open the skin. Now to reaon upon the accidents that befell M. Des Trapieres by this bite, as they are et down in his Letter; I ee nothing in them that is not very natural, and very credible. For, although the angred Spirits had entred by the openings made by the mall teeth; yet they could not penetrate the fleh, nor mingle with the blood, becaue thoe apertures were not deep enough, and they could do no more but to make their effort 'twixt the fleh and skin; whence follow'd the welling of the lip and face, and the impreion of the pale colour, which appear'd there during a moneth; which accidents might at firt have been eaily prevented by one only doe of the volatil Salt of Vipers, which would have made the enraged Spirits to tranpire, that lodged between the fleh and the skin, and could find no entry to pas further. As to the little bladder, which was formed at the place of the bite, and the two or three drops of dark liquor that iued afterwards, that was nothing but a little erous moiture that had been gather'd there from the neighbouring parts, and that had been caued by the compreion of the Ligature,
and by the bruiing made by the teeth and Jawes at the time of the biting, and without any intervention of the yellow liquor, which beides its innocence, could not have entred through uch mall apertures.

After o many Experiments, and upon o many Reflexions which I have made, as well on the yellow liquor, as on the irritated pirits of Vipers, I cannot comprehend, how the Animals of Sign. Redi could dye all and without any exception by the intromiion of the yellow liquor into the wounds, he had made in them, and by the biting of heads ever'd, or by that of entire Vipers that had been dead everal days. I have too many experiments to the contrary, and too many witnees, to put it out of doubt, and to fix me in my firt opinion.

But, to the end that among the Truths by me advanced, and coniting in matter of fact, the publick may find wherewith to be atisfied; I thought my elf obliged to explain my ene upon thee matters, and to form to my elf the Objections, that may be made againt me.

I ay therefore concerning the Tellow Liquor, That nothing can act from it elf, but according to its nature, the dipoition of the matter of which it is compoed, and the force
of its activity. For example, you will not find in River Water, the tate, trength, nor particles that are found in Wine, nor will that inebriate like this: it hath not the acrimony nor penetrancy of Urine, neither the colour not bitternes of Gall: The Spirit of Wine, that is freed from the aqueous parts, which hindred the Wine from producing the effects it was capable of, is much more ubtile and trong, then the ame wine whence it hath been drawn: The Volatil Salt of Wine hath quite another penetrating force than the Urine which contained it before its ublimation: And not to go from my ubject; the volatil Salt of Vipers is very different from the fleh and bones of them, whence it hath been extracted; and, though in mall quantity, it will work more in a moment as well by its odour as its piercing vertue, than ten times as much of that matter, whence it hath been drawn, could effect in many hours: The bileous, harp, alt and pirituous eroity, that is often form'd in our bodies, will uddenly produce inflammations in the eyes, tumors in the cheeks, gums, throat, and many other parts, as alo Putuls, St. Anthony fire, and the Gangrene it elf; and all that it does by the compoition of its parts, and the force of its activity; whereas the thick and vicous
Phlegme will do no uch thing, but chargeth nature only by its weight, cold, and tenacity: This Phlegme, I ay, will ever be incapable of working with quicknes, and it cannot produce any effect out very lowly, and in proportion to its power, which is extreamly confined.

So then, it is not the nature of the yellow liquor, to pas wiftly to remote parts, and there to act with vigor and violence; which is oberved in the poion of a Viper. I ay, that a tough, vicous, and in a manner inipid Saliva, cannot make any great progres in a moment. I affirm beides, that 'tis impoible, it hould corporally enter into the holes made by the teeth, which are very mall and almot inviible, and that it hould alo pas through the cavities of the teeth, and much les through their Pores, if any would have them pas that way. I ay further, that although the teeth of a Viper hould be all over imbued with that Juyce at the time of her biting; the skin of the Animal bitten, and the fleh it elf, if need were, would keep it out of the bitten place, and hinder it from entring there; That though it hould be able to enter, it mut have a fit place to receive it, a great paage to go through, and a long time to arrive to the parts
remote; I ay alo, that though it were arrived there, (if that were poible,) it could never act beyond the forces, which nature hath retrained it to.

Beides, if this yellow liquor were capable of any coniderable operation, it would not fail to dicover it either in whole or in part, when 'tis wallow'd and got into the tomach; where the place, the heat, and all things would eem to concur either to make it ferment, if its matter were dipoed for it, or to reduce its power into action: For, by paing out of the tomach into the intetins it would infect the Chyle, and make of it a poion, which would be carried jointly with it through the milky veels, and through the Thoracique Ductus's, o happily dicover'd by the illutrious M. Pecquet, to decend into the Heart with the blood, the which is the matter, on which the poion of Vipers does o particularly exert its dominion. And this way is much more eaie and large, than that of the opening, made by the teeth, by which this juyce cannot o much as enter. I ay this further, that, if it were uch as Sign. Redi makes it to be, it would, being taken at the mouth and let down into the tomach, impres upon the places of its paage, and thoe of its tay, ome mark or other of its power, epecially
if it did contain any Arenical Salts, which would not fail, oon to manifet themelves either by their tate or by ome other effects: And yet all thoe that hall tate or wallow this yellow liquor, hall never perceive any malignity whether great or mall, neither in the mouth, nor in the tomach, nor elewhere. I conclude therefore from all thee coniderations, that this juyce contains in it no part at all, that is able to diolve, or coagulate, or dicompoe any part of our body; & that it hath not any quality, manifet or occult, to hew that 'tis capable of doing o.

I add moreover, that this juyce, as flat and alivous as it is, is always found o yellow in all parts of France, that it can hardly be les colour'd than 'tis in Italy; and that they both mut have altogether alike qualities, or, at leat, very near uch. And it would be to no purpoe, to alledge in favour of Sign. Redi, that the diverity of places and climate, or that of aliments might be able to change the nature of Vipers, and caue that manifet difference, there is between his Experiments and mine. For, although ome diverity may be oberved in other things, there can be found none in this; and if there could be ome difference, it cannot be that the nature of the yellow juyce, and that of the Spirits hould
be quite changed; ince we find in France the ame marks in that liquor, which Sign. Redi hath found and decribed in that of Italy, and ince our Vipers, without any intervention of that juyce, do kill as nimbly as his can do.

But I think it would be much, if in the yellow liquor, or in the enraged pirits, there could be oberv'd any mall degree of quality, tronger or weaker in Italy than in France. For, I have by a great number of experiments made it out, that all the Vipers of France, though taken in very different places, and often uch as are ix core Leagues ditant from one another, have their poion altogether alike, and do kill equally. Whence I inferr, that the difference of the Vipers of Italy and France, cannot be coniderable; ince Dauphiné, which is a Province in France that furniheth us with many of them, and is very mountainous as well as Italy, borders upon Picmont, which is the beginning of Italy; and that the ame Dauphiné, abounds in Vipers in its utmot extremity; and ince alo all Vipers, we get from thence, have their yellow liquor always very innocent, though high colour'd. And I can truly ay, that thoe Vipers, that have erv'd me mot both in my firt and lat experiments, were mot of them ent me out of Dauphiné, and that I was willing
to make ue of uch, as being commonly bigger than mot of thoe that were ent me out of Poictou; that, at leat, which erv'd me to bite the five firt Pigeons, which I pake of in my firt Experiments; and that which bit the eaven lat Pullets and Pigeons, were of thoe of Dauphiné, and even of the bigger ort that could be procured.

And it would have been to no purpoe to have ued any tooth of a Viper ever'd from the head, and much les to wipe it dry with ome bread crums, in hopes it hould kill any Animal by pricking it therewith; eeing the teeth, that had of the yellow liquor upon them, without being eparated from the dead heads, were not able to do any harm, no not thoe of live ones, without the concurrence of the enraged pirits. And if ometimes I have made ue of bread-crums, ometimes of a ine linnen ragg, to wipe away all the yellow liquor of the veicles, that was never but in live Vipers; to hew, that it was not that liquor which did kill, but the vexed Spirits only, entring by means of the biting.

We are not to imagine neither, that a Viper teareth by biting, unles having made her to thrut her teeth into the fleh of ome animal, you do immediately after draw her away by the ret of her body: We are not, I
ay, to pretend, that a Viper doth, by biting of her own accord, make any great opening, at which the yellow liquor is able to enter. For, he doth no more but thrut in her teeth far enough, and preently draw them out again, with as much eae as a Cat draws out his claws when he will. Beides, you cannot perceive but two very little holes, which do alo eem as 'twere cloed again by the fleh, and which would hardly be dicern'd, if the pain of the bite, or the accidents enuing, did not oblige us to look very narrowly to it.

We alo never ee, that the poion fatens it elf to the part bitten, nor that the evil begins by a mortification, or by a gangrene there. For, if that were o, and if the venom did lodge at the entry, it would be much more eaie to mater it. I know alo by many Experiments, that the poion never tays at the place where it enters, but ininuates it elf very nimbly into the Veines, to mingle with the blood; epecially if the bite hath open'd for it a paage free enough to arrive there. I know, that there it produces afterwards thoe troubleome accidents, which enue upon the biting; and that latly it caueth death, if it be not prevented by a quick relief. Which clearly hews, that a poion of this nature mut needs have dipoitions to
penetrate, very differing from thoe that appear in a yellow liquor, that is incapable of all udden motion and operation.

It would alo prove an ueles labour, to uck at the place of the biting, in hopes of getting out from thence a Juyce, which could not enter there. And though I do not diprove this way of uccours on uch occaion; yet I know, that all what the ucking can do, is, to fetch out again part of the enraged pirits, that had enter'd by the openings of the bite. I know alo, that a pecifique remedy, taken at the mouth, is far better.

I would be in vain, to object unto me the example of the eed of Animals, which, notwithtanding its vicoity, erves daily to propagate that Species which produces it; and that it could in like manner come to pas in the yellow liquor to convey the venom in the biting. For beides that the eed is the puret and mot elaborat part which an animal can produce; it is alo accompanied with tore of Spirits; and there needs, beides, the concurrence of many other means as well to introduce and to receive it, as to form and perfect the Foetus: There is moreover neceary an aitance of abundance of pirits from the mothers ide; a juyce proportionate and proper for its nourihment and
increae, and a ufficient time for the ame. Whereas the yellow liquor, that can pas for nothing but a juyce excreted out of the Salival Glanduls, after it had been ent thither from the brain and the neighbouring parts, and that is detitute of pirits and of all dipoition to act; wants alo a paage ufficient to intromit it, and a place proper to lodge in. And if you hould grant it an entry, and a place to ojourn in; it mut have a much longer time than the eed, of which I was peaking. But with all this time and all the other circumtances, it would till be incapable of working any thing at all perfect, and perih of it elf; without any remarkable production.

If any hould ay, That this yellow liquor may have pirits proper and proportionate to its nature, and that they are not wanting to make the poion work at the moment of the biting; but that, being drawn out of the veicles, and expoed to the Air, thoe pirits are diipated, and thereby render it incapable of all action: I anwer, That, without taying upon what I have amply made out of its innocence in all kind of ues, Signor Redi himelf contradicts it, as I have mentioned above; ince he pretends, that the Juyce even of uch Vipers as have been dead for everal days, &
that is dryed to boot, ceaeth not to ininuate its venom without any intervention of pirits, when it is put into wounds. But, beides all that, many Experiments have evinced to me, that death follows the biting without any intervention of the yellow liquor, and then when it hath been perfectly wiped away. Moreover, it is well known, that 'tis the nature of pirits, to be in motion, to faten themelves to, and to follow the parts that have mot of them, as for example, the blood.
