It is alo to be noted, that the pirits, that do ininuate the poion, are not of the nature of thoe that follow the ordinary motion of the blood of the animal; that they do not joyn themelves to it, as thoe; and that neither of them have any union with the yellow liquor; which is but a meer excrement: But that the Spirits, I peak of, do form themelves in the moment that the Viper conceives the Idea of revenging her elf; and they need not the embarament of uch a dull and vicous juyce, which is not qualified to follow them, nor to pas through the imperceptible pores of the teeth, which the pirits only can penetrate, no more then they can any ways enter through the holes, which the teeth have made. In a word; the nature of a gros, tough and vicous juyce is not, to act, penetrate, and be
wiftly carried to the mot remote parts of the body; but that belongs to pirituous ubtances, to go and come where gros corporall ones cannot. Thee are the only pirits, that can ubvert the whole Oeconomy of the body; they are they, that diturb the circulation of the blood, and that corrupt it; they are they, that top the natural and animal pirits, and hinder them from paing to the parts of the body as they were wont to do; and latly, 'tis by the let of them, that the death of the Animal uually enueth the biting.

As to what may be objected, that 'tis very difficult, o exactly to evacuate the yellow liquor, that there remain none at all; and that it may very well come to pas, that a little of it intervenes in all bitings: I anwer, that beides that this is alo againt the opinion of Sign. Redi, and which he hath renounced in his firt Aertion; the Salival Glanduls, though many in number, yet are too mall and have too little capacity to contain juyce enough to furnih for that purpoe; and that that cannot be expected but from great animals, that have thoe Salival glanduls and the other parts far bigger: And though it were poible, they hould ufficiently furnih, I do maintain, that the impoibility of intromitting that juyce, and its evinced innocence,
ought to uffice for confuting this Objection.

Yet this I hall here ay in favour of Sign. Redi, That I doubt not but that this yellow liquor, as Salivous and Excrementitious as it is, contains its Volatil Salt, as well as all the other parts of a Viper, and all the parts of Animals, and even all their excrements, and that conequently it is to be reputed pirituous. But then, beides that thee pirituous ubtances are never hurtful, they are yet too intimately mixed and locked in with their matter, and they cannot produce their effects without being eparated from it; which cannot be but by a violent heat, and in veels fit for it. I ay therefore, that by art there may be extracted a true Volatil Salt out of this yellow liquor, & even without any addition or mixture of other matter; which may be proved to be of the ame nature with that of the other parts of a Viper; and that 'tis o far from being able to work like poion, that t'is very proper and effectual to mater all the ill accidents, which the bite of a Viper may caue; of which I do accue the enraged pirits alone. Since therefore Sign. Redi hath dried and laid aide the yellow liquor of two hundred and fifty Vipers, and may eaily obtain much more of it; 'tis in his power to extract uch a alt out of it, when he pleaeth, to verifie
what I was jut now aying: And if, to ave himelf that labour, by reaon of his other important occupations, he hall pleae to end me a competent quantity thereof, I do with all my heart offer my elf to prepare it for him, thereby to let him ee not only the innocence of this juyce, but alo the great benefit, that is hid in it.

Concerning the Bilious Breath of a Viper, that may be charged to intervene with this yellow liquor, and to envenom it; I am of opinion, that that is nothing but a diguie of the enraged pirits. I aert, That the true Breath of a Viper is ever innocent, how bilious oever it be repreented; that there iues not any ill cent out of her throat, nor out of her guts, nor from the parts made to void the excrements; That Vipers among other marks are in this different from Snakes, that thee have their excrements and the parts containing them very fetide and of a mell of tinking Urine; whereas you cannot perceive any ill mell in any part of a Viper; that the Spirits which carry the venom are quite another thing than the breath coming from the Lungs; that thoe pirits have no union nor correpondence with the Bilious humour; that they are not formed but at the intant of the irritation; and latly, that they need no
uch thing as an excrementitious and ueles liquor, pretended to intervene, fit for nothing but to gard the paage of the place, through which the vexed pirits have entred.

But the better to hew the impoibility of the intervention of this breath, and to make it appear, that it never contributes any thing to the poion; you may take notice, that a Vipers head cut off, eparate from the Lungs and all communication with the Gall, and incapable to yield any breath, and deprived even of all that yellow liquor; yet failes not to kill by its biting as long as 'tis alive, if the animal have been provoked; jut as would come to pas, if a bite were made by the head of a Viper that is whole and alive, if no remedy were applied.

Touching the Communication, that may alo be pretended to be between the bladder of Gall and the yellow liquor, by reaon of ome reemblance of colour; I ay, that, beides that my Sentiments in thee matters are very conform to thoe of Sign. Redi; that we have both of us jutified the innocence of the juyce contained in the Bladder of Gall; that we have denied, there is any veel carrying this better juyce into the veicles of the gums, to make that yellow liquor which is found
there: and latly, that we have unanimouly contradicted the errors of the Antients about this pretended channel; beides this; I ay, the truth of what we have affirmed is very eaie to prove, by tating the yellow liquor of the Gall, which is very bitter and very harp, though very innocent, and by comparing it with that of the veicles of the Gums, which is very flat, though equally innocent. The ame may be yet better made out by diecting one or more Vipers; where, no more than in Serpents and all other animals, you will never find any veel, that carries this bile of the Bladder of Gall to the Gums; and you will there ee nothing but veins and arteries filled With true blood. Of this there will be no doubt, if you pleae only to tate it; for you will find nothing but the ordinary tate of blood. To be yet more aur'd of it, you may tate all that runs out of the body of a Viper when the head is ever'd from her; for you hall find no bitternes at all, nor other tat but that of blood. And beides, having amply verified, that the yellow liquor comes from the Salival glanduls alone, and having given a very exact decription of them; I think it needles to ay any more of it, what ever the Antients may have written, or the Moderns may ay of that ubject.

To come now to the enraged Spirits of a Viper, which I do aure to be the true and only eat of the poion; methinks Sign. Redi hath no reaon to oppoe my opinion, when I do interes in it the imagination of the Viper, or her Idea of revenge, for the formation of thoe Spirits. I might here alledge what Van Helmont aith in his Chapt. De Tumul •
Petis, viz. That not only the Idea and the Imagination of terror are formed in the inward Archeus of the peron invaded by the Plague; but that the Toad, which hath, as he aith, a perpetual hatred againt man, finding himelf taken, and hanged by one of his hind-legs, and in a condition of dying, conceives an Idea and an imagination of terror by the ight of the man, that often preents himelf before his eyes, and whom he looks upon as his capital enemy, and that the ame Idea or the ame phancy of terror, which the Toad hath conceived by this means, forms in him uch impreions and qualities, as are permanent even after his death. Then this Author will, that of this body, that dyed in thoe Ideas of terror, mingled with the parts that have iued thence, and with the wax that hall have received them, you hall make Trocheque's, which being taken inwardly, and carried about you, or applied, hall have the
virtue of curing as well as preerving from the Plague, by mortifying by their Specifique quality the terror which the inward Archeus of the peron may have conceived of this evil. Now ince this Sentiment of Van Helmont hath found place in the minds of many men, yery capable to judge of it; who have been thence induced even to make exactly that preparation of Toads, which he hath taught in the ame Chapter, and which I can aure I have my elf made to atisfie the deire of very able Phyitians; having alo known many perons giving great credit to it, and carrying continually about them of thoe Trocheques whilt there was talk of the Plague; methinks, that the formation of the enraged pirits, which I acribe to the Idea and imagination of revenge, conceived by the Viper when he is vexed, is incomparably more maintainable, and much eaier to be comprehended, as well as the entry of the angred Spirits through the Openings made by the Teeth; becaue not only thee Apertures are wont to be deep, but alo becaue the teeth being hollow, erve for a Funnel to intromit thoe pirits, that accompany the biting, and that produce afterwards in the body bitten thoe dimal effects of vengeance, which the Viper had conceived when he
felt the ill done her; And the letting in of thoe Spirits through the cavity of thoe teeth is o much the more eaie, becaue there is alo at the end of each great tooth a hole, which, though very mall and almot undicernable by the eye, may yet be dicerned by a Microcope, & hath accordingly been lately een in ome publick Aemblies at Paris, in the preence even of perons very affectionate to Sign. Redi.

What hall we ay of the imagination of Fright and Contraint, that a Toad alo imprees in a Wecel, which having een and been een by that ugly animal, at a certain eaon of the year, and always in ummer, can not avoyd to run a pretty while round about it making a continual hrill noye, as if he cried for help, whilt the Toad remains moveles with his throat open; and which after a long troubleome motion is contrain'd to come and render her elf into that throat. The thing is too well known in divers places of France to doubt of it; and I can aure to have heretofore een it my elf; and that after I had well oberv'd and withal wondred at the force of thoe Idea's, appearing in the agitation of the Weeel, and in her being contrained to fall into the mouth of the Toad,
I had the atisfaction to kill the Toad in that moment, and o to ave the Weeel, which quickly run away, finding her elf deliver'd by the death of the animal, which was followed by the extinction of thoe Ideas, that before had had o much power over her. This effect cannot be adcribed to the foam, nor to any material part of the Toad, ince the Weeel flyes from him naturally, and falls not into his mouth but in pight of her teeth. Beides that the foam of the Toad, which the Weeel failed not to meet with in his throat, can work nothing, eeing the Weeel aved her elf immediately after the death of the animal. We therefore mut needs eek for the caue of all thee effects in the Spirits.

More-over, what will Sign. Redi ay of a mad dog, which, in the pervertion of all his enes and of all the ordinary functions of his body, breaths after nothing but michief, and makes it his buines to reduce into the ame mierable condition all men he ees, and even his own mater, as well as all animals he can come near and bite? If then the mad Dog hath the power to make pas the ame Idea's and the ame imagination, which have eized on him, into all the creatures
that he can come to bite, and into man himelf, though of a very different oul and nature from his, by doing no more than with the edge of his teeth to touch the uperfice of the skin, and that through his coaths that may retain and wipe off all the foam adhering to the teeth, and lyable to be accued of having a hand in the michief; as is very well oberv'd by Van Helmont in the ame Chapter? If, I ay, this dog hath the power of communicating his evil to all orts of animals, from one to another, without a limit, and without excepting any kind; Why hould he think it incredible, that a Viper is able by her biting to carry her enraged pirits into the bodies of uch men and other animals as he can light upon; That thee pirits are capable to kill the animal bitten; and that they effect this by the perturbation and corruption, they introduce into the whole mas of blood; foramuch as they do manifetly hinder its circulation, and the communication of the natural pirits, that were wont to be conveyed into all the parts? Conidering withal, that they do not extend themelves as far as thoe of the bite of a mad Dog; eeing none of the Animals bitten by a Viper, have any venom diffuible either by their biting,
or otherwie, as long as they live, and that they may be afely handled, and even without danger eaten after their death.

I ay beides, that if it be true, that a man, who hath at all times the ame pitle and the ame teeth, & who hath them not pointed nor haped like thoe of a Viper, is capable to introduce the Gangrene, and to caue death it elf by a bite made by him in a rage; whereas another and longer bite, made by the ame man not enraged, is not accompanied with any ill accident, and is healed like a imple wound; This being true, I ay, we ought to think it neither trange nor impoible, that a Viper, which hath long and piercing teeth, and which hews the force of her being vexed by the nimblenes of her biting, hould be able, by biting when enraged, to make animals feel the mortal effects of her vexed pirits.

What hall we ay of the pricking of a Tarantula how light oever? hall we declare it to be exempt from the idea and imagination of this little animal, ince it imprees it o trongly and differently upon perons that have been pricked therewith, inomuch that it perverts in part the enes and pirits, conforms them to his tirring and skipping
nature, and contrains them at certain and et times to continual dancing for everal days, and which having left a contumacious leaven of the ame idea's, faileth not to produce the ame effects every year, and, if you may believe Authors, as long as the Tarantula liveth, and until the ame idea's be extinct by its death. And though I doubt not but that Sign. Redi hath een very many examples of perons pricked by Tarantula's, there being tore of them in Italy; yet I hall not forbear here to recite that of a Neapolitan Souldier, who hath been thee four years among the French infantry. This Souldier, whom his Camarads call'd Tarante, becaue he had been pricked by a Tarantula, is till to this very day in the Royal Regiment of Rouillon. He never failed to feel every year at a determinate time (viz. about the 24th of July) the effects of that ting, which he had receiv'd before he came into France. He was always ure of the time about two or three days near it. And when the ideas of the ting were found exalted to a degree capable to produce their effects, he began to dance, and deired to hear without interruption the Violins, which the Officers of that Regiment caued to be play'd for him out of charity; to
which he anwer'd continually, keeping time very well, without being tired, for three days, eating and drinking, without interruption of his dance; and being very impatient of any dicontinuance of the play of the Violins, and that the more, if the intermiion was any thing long; for then he became altogether livid, and fell into grievous woundings. He pleaed himelf whilt he danced, to have in his hands everal naked words, one after another; to ee about him many Looking-glaes, to behold himelf in them dancing; to be environed with much people, and, that he might hinder them from going away, to take from them their Gloves, Ribbons, and uch other things; being very careful to keep all he had taken from them unto the fourth day, which being come, his eagernes to dance abated, and at length quite ceaed; he remembring all he had done, and knowing all that were about him, to every one of whom he rendred very exactly and without any mitake all he had taken from them, though he had to do with a thouand people. After which time, he pas'd the remainder of that year, and the whole interval of his Paroxyines without any inclination to dance. He was naturally melancholick,
in appearance of no great parts, neither had he learn'd to dance. He hath been een thus dancing every year by thouands of people, and particularly in the Camp Royal Anno 1670. where the King himelf and the whole Court aw him. And this hath been o beneficial to him, that the ordinary time is pat this year without any aault of this evil, which he had great apprehenions of, finding himelf at that time engaged in a march, and fearing he hould want Violins at the time that the it hould take him.

Now ince the pricking of this Animal, though very mall, and in a manner like that of a mall fly, being made even thorough tockings or cloaths, is able to act equally upon the body and the mind of the peron tung; as leaving behind uch long and trong impreions, and cauing uch irkome returns; To what can we adcribe all thoe different effects, if it be not to the idea or imagination of the animal tinging, or of the peron tung. 'Tis needles, to alledge here the effects of the idea or imagination of Women with Child, nor of that of Jacob's Sheep. I think I have aid enough to jutifie the poibility of the idea or imagination of a Vipers revengefulnes, for the forming
of angry pirits, ufficient to impute unto them all the venom, and to exclude from it the yellow liquor.

After this, Sign. Redi mut not wonder, if I, who make profeion of Chymitry, (of which I have the honour to read publick Lectures in the Garden Royal) who doe every day exercie my elf in eparating the pirituous parts from the gros ones in mixt inanimat bodies; and who have not been able to find in any corporeal and enible matter the true caue of the trange and uddain productions, oberved in the biting of a live Viper; If I, after all this, I ay, have thought my elf obliged to eek for it in the Spirits; if having found it there, I have abandon'd his party, and communicated to the publick the dicovery I have made.

Yet I am not over-much urpried, that Sign, Redi, being in this matter prepoes'd by corporeal gros things, till perits in his entiment, ince in the preparations, that do altogether depend of my profeion, and which I ought to know well, he rejects pirituous ubtances, which he relihes not, ticking only to the more material, which are the leat, and in very mall quantity; which doth not keep him from believing
them to be the bet. You may ee, what he writeth of it about the end of pag. 76. and at the beginning of pag. 77, of his firt Letter of Obervations, in thee words.

In quete nuè naturali Oervationi ho conuinato gran quantitá, &c. That is, In thee my natural Obervations I have pent a great quantity of Vipers, making of them daily a very great laughter; and, to extract the ubtile from the ubtil (if I may o peak) I always laid aide and kept all their fleh and bones, which being dryed in a Furnace, and afterwards by a quick fire with long and great labour burnt and reduced to ahes, I thence drew the Salt with Fountain-water, and purified it, and reduced it into a kind of Chrytal, &c.

Thoe that know all the parts of which the body of a Viper is compoed, will certainly wonder, that a peron o judicious and knowing hath not found, that the chief and bet part of a Viper conits in its volatil Salt, and that that Salt would not fail to avolate and to be wated by that preparation or rather detruction, which Sign. Redi hath ued to extract the Salt of Vipers. They will quickly ee, that when he would draw the ubtil from the ubtil (as he peaks) he did
quite the contrary, and expelled and diipated the volatil and better parts, returning only the gros, the fixed and the leat. They will oon judg, that he hould not have given himelf all that labour and pain, which he aith he hath taken, to ucceed o ill in his work; and that he had done much better, with ilence to pas over his proces, then to publih it. The way, by him taken, will be found, I think, received from the Antients, who knew not, that all Animals abound in Volatil, and have little of Fixed Salt: And his preparation, which is very eaie, would have pleaed better in thoe times, epecially in Italy, then that great and laborious Preparation of the Salt of Vipers, which was made with o great an Apparatus, and of which I have already given my thoughts, when I dicoured of the Remedies drawn from Vipers.

I alo foreee, that Sign. Redi will not receive any greater advantage by triving to attribute to himelf the firt dicovery of the Salival glanduls, which I found on both the Temples of both Male and Female Vipers, and which I have decribed and delineated in my Anatomy of Vipers: For, he will not be able to perwade it to thoe, who hall
ee pag. 44. of his firt Letter of Obervations the dicoure following;

Se non timai vergogna criver enza altra riprova, &c. That is, If I did not think it a hame, to write, without other proof, what came into my phancy, I might ay perhaps, that that yellow liquor is by no other way intromitted into the above aid gums of the teeth but by thoe Salival Conduits, found out by the famousThomas Wharton, and hewn in this Court by Lorenzo Billini, a learned young man and of great expectation, in other Animals beides Man, and particularly in Staggs, and Wood-peckers: Moreover that under thoe Gums there are two mall Glanduls, found by me in all Vipers. Yet I would not have you rely upon this thought of mine, becaue it may prove a Chimera, as I believe it to be one,&c.

I cannot comprehend, how Sign. Redi, after he hath poken of the Salival Conduits as of a thing that came into his phancy, and by a perhaps, that is to ay, not knowing it; and who declareth, that he was aham'd to write of a thing without verifying it; who exhorts his friend to whom he writes, not to relye on his thoughts, and who adds, that it may prove a Chimera; I know not, I ay,
how, after he hath written all this, he can pretend to be the inventor of the Salival Glanduls, and their Pipes: For pag. 55 and 56. of his firt Letter peaking of the yellow liquor, he adds,

E queto veleno altro non è, &c. That is,This venom is nothing ele but that liquor, which humects the Palat, and tagnates in thoe gums that invet the teeth, not transmitted thither from the Bladder of Gall, but bred in the whole head, and conveyed perhaps to the gums by ome Salival conduits, which perhapsare there inerted.

Where the word perhaps, yet twice again repeated, doth ufficiently hew, that Sign. Redi did peak of the Salival conduits no otherwie than as of a thing he was not at all aured of. And though he may ay, that he hath had thoughts of it ooner than I, (who have not medled with Vipers but ome years after his firt Letter,) that what he had written of it gave me from that time occaion and a deire to eek for thoe Pipes and the Glanduls that might convey thither the yellow liquor; that the belief, he had of the Generation of this juyce in the whole head, induced me to earch for the Salival Glanduls higher and farther off than the place under the
bottom of the veicles; and that I doubt not, that himelf might have found thee true Glanduls, if he would have taken pains for it. I anwer, that, ince he hath not done it, he ought not to be offended at my having labour'd for him, and ucceeded in o doing: Neither hath he any right to deny, that I have firt found, decribed, and to the life repreented the two heaps of Salival Glanduls of a Viper with all their Veels, as well for forming, as conveying the yellow liquor into the Veicles that cover the great teeth.

As to what Sign. Redi aith of me, peaking of the Authors of my Book, that I have changed the words, under the bottom, into thoe, at the bottom of the veicles of the gums, and there ought in vain for the two mall Glanduls, which he aures to have found there in all Vipers: I anwer, that whilt he is critical as to the letter of the words, I keep to the truth of the matter of fact: And I can aure, to have earched with much care, not only in the whole bottom of the veicles, but every where under the bottom of them, but have not found any, whether great or mall Glanduls, nor any thing of the colour of a Glandul, nor that came any way near to their form.

I put it then for a truth, that there is not to be found any Glandul neither in nor under the bottom of the veicles, and that under the bottom there is nothing but the gritly bone that gives the hape to the noe of a Viper; the two harp ends of the two advanced bones of the skull, to which the two great teeth are firmly annexed; the conduit of the mell, that of the hearing; ome mall vein, ome little Artery, ome little Nerve, the extremity of a Mucle, and the two ends of the Salival Channels that dicharge into the veicles; as you may ee it in a manner decribed in the Anatomy made of it by me.
After this, Signor Redi himelf hews, that it was impoible, there hould be Glanduls under the bottom of the veicles, ince he aith, pag. 38. of his lat Letter.

Ne io poteva mai crivere, &c. that is, Nor could I at all write, that thoe Glanduls lay in the bottom of the veicles, if I was of opinion, that the yellow liquor did run into them after it had paed through the Salival conduits, which yet I imagined might have their Origin from or connexion with thoe two Glanduls een by me, and therefore mut needs be in a cituation a little ditant from the veicles, and not in the bottom of them.

For ince he aith, to have meant, that the yellow juyce took its coure thorough the Salival conduits before its coming into the veicles; He cannot find a way long enough, nor a ditance great enough, for the need of long conduits, from the place under the bottom unto that which is in the bottom of the veicles: For, there would have needed nothing but a little opening in the ame bottom, to receive the juyce iuing out of the two little Glanduls he hath poken of. And he hews ufficiently, that he cannot maintain thoe two mall Glanduls under the bottom, where he would have them to be, ince now he will needs have them a little ditant from the veicles, that he may find, in the intervall, a pace ufficient for the veels that are neceary to the coure of this yellow liquor. Beides, that it is altogether impoible for two mall Glanduls to furnih all that yellow liquor, which preents it elf in the veicles; ince the two great heaps by me found in the two Temples and behind the Orbits of the eyes of a Viper, can hardly furnih each about a drop in the pace of 24 hours, after the veicles have been well voided. Moreover, it is very eaie to judge by what Sign. Redi aith in his Firt Letter, that he undertood not, the Salival Glands were eated, as
they are, on the two Temples, nor o near the skull; ince he aith, that what came into his phancy, was, that the head of a Viper did not convey that yellow juyce but by certain alival conduits. For if he had been of another mind, he would not have poken but of glands; or, at leat, he would have begun with them before he had poken of the conduits, which hews alo ufficiently, that by this means he hath as 'twere inverted the order of nature: For, intead of placing the Glands cloe to the skul, and afterwards the alival conduits; he hath begun with thee, and would have them immediately to receive the juyce of the Brain, and to carry them to the veicles of the gums; and that his two pretended glanduls are eated between the extremity of thee conduits, and the bottom of the veicles; though none be there, and it would be altogether ueles, they hould be there, becaue there are none but they that can at the beginning uck & diget the humidities of the brain and the neighbouring parts, and end them into the veicles of the gums by the conduits appointed for this office.

But when Sign. Redi accues me of having taken the bottom of the veicles for that which is under the bottom of them, and of not having rightly undertood, as he peaks,
the Tocan tongue; I may ay, that himelf hath not very well apprehended, nor duly explained the French terms, ued by me; ince he aith at the end of pag. 35. and at the beginning of p. 36. of the ame lat letter.

Sovra de chi gli, Autori delle novelle experience affermano, &c. That is, Whereupon the Authors of the New Experiments do affirm, that they could never ee uch Glanduls as I had named; but that intead of them they had found two others, which they call Salival, thus by them decribed, p. 31.

For neither in all that he hath afterwards taken the pains to trancribe out of my book on that ubject, nor in all the ret of my Section upon the Salival Glanduls, he can have read; that I ay to have found two Glanduls, but, Glanduls; there being a great difference in good French, between Deux Glandes, and Des Glandes, two Glands, and, Glands. And when, decribing the Glanduls, I ay, that they are eated on the two ides of the Craniuns, I ay afterwards, that there are many mall ones joyned together, which may be call'd Conglomerate Glanduls. And yet more; I peak of an Heap of Glanduls; o far am I from peaking only of one or two Glanduls, as Sign. Redi hath repreented me to have done.

And ince, in hopes of better maintaining
his caue, he hath given himelf the trouble of copying word for word, in his lat Letter, only the mot general place of my Book, and that which was the leat contrary to it, in my Section of the Salival Glands. To hew therefore on my part, that the Glands, found by me, are very different, and that even they are quite another thing, than the two mall ones poken of by him; I thought my elf obliged to trancribe hither out of my book what he thought not neceary for him. For in the ame Section, p. 30. (in the Englih verion, p. 33) I peak thus of the alival Glands.

Thee Glands are found in all the heads of Vipers, both Males and Females; they are eated on both ides, and joining to the skull, in the hind-part of each round of the eyes, and at the ame height with them. There are many mall ones joined together, which may be call'd Conglomerate Glands, that are eaily ditinguihable by their form and colour, which is different from the Mucles, neighbouring to them, and of which there is one, that may be call'd Temporal,which in part covers them by its extremity. This heap of Glands appears there of the bignes of the neighbouring eye, and extending it elf in length, continues its progres in the Orbite of the eye, below and in part behind the eye. Each Gland hath its little Lymphatique veel,
which parts from it as from a little Teat, and goes digorging it elf into a greater veel, that runs all along and under thee Glands, and paeth into the Veicle of the Gum, and terminates in the midt of the Articulation, which the root of the great teeth makes with the advancing corner of the aid Orbite, and with the little Bone, which by its other end is articulated in the middle of the upper jaw. This principal veel, which being conider'd alone, is very little in appearance, but is not o in effect, eeing it receives the dicharge of all the mall veels that come from each Gland, empties it elf into the bag of the gums, and carries thither that Salival juyce, which may have qualities approaching to thoe of the Saliva or Spitle of man, or of the foam or drivel of divers other Animals.
The Nerve, which erves in the Notrils to the faculty of Hearing, runs for ome pace along thee Glands, which are alo, as I have already aid, mall Veins and Arteries.

But having well conider'd the ubtance, quality & cituation of thee Glands, we judged their formation not to be in vain; but that their Ue, in all likelyhood, was, to receive the humidities both of the Brain, the Eyes, and the neighbouring parts; and that their dicharge was very convenient, and even very
neceary to the parts, which receive that liquor; as well for moitening the ligaments of the great teeth, and to keep them in a condition of bending at uch time when the Viper will bite, as for bedewing and increaing the teeth, which Nature hath formed and et in the midt of this Juice.

For the ret, examining and tating the Glands as well as the Juice, we found a tate altogether like that of the Gums, which Sign. Redi hath decribed; namely, very near the tate of the Oyle of Almonds, without all bitternes, though it leave, a while after, a little acrimony in the mouth, uch as may be dicern'd in all kind of Spitle.

I could add here, what I aid of the Salival Glands of Snakes, their difference from thoe of Vipers; and I could alledge, that I believe my elf to be likewie the firt Dicoverer of them. But becaue o prolix a Citation might prove tedious, and that thoe that deire to have more light therein, may eaily find the ret in the above-cited Section of my Book, I hall not trancribe it hither.

Mean time 'tis very eaie to judge from my whole Dicoure, and from the exact Decription, made by me, of thee Glands,
and their neighbouring parts, that they were not known to me by Phancy. Their cituation very ditant from that place under, and even from the ides of, the bottom of the veicles of the gums, hews ufficiently, that they are neither in nor under the bottom of thoe veicles, as Sign. Redi hath pretended; and their great number makes it appear, that 'tis quite another thing, than the two litle Glanduls he peaks of, and which are not to be found neither.

I intreat the Reader, well to conider thoe I have dicover'd, as they are repreented in my third Cutt, as well in that part where the Temples are of a Head cut, mark'd C, (where their hape and cituation is repreented to the life, as they hew themelves before they are ever'd;) as in the incloure of a Vipers celeton, which is there alo exhibited; where he may ee them in their upper and lower appearance, drawn out of the Head, and by their ligaments fatned to the hind-part of the Eyes, and to the body of the Brain. I came not to the full knowledge of them till after much pains, and a very long and particular earch. I did not content my elf to eek a great while in the bottom,
and under the bottom of the veicles of the gums; but, to find thee Glands, I have flead and diected a great number of Vipers heads, as dextrouly and nicely as I could; and I have ued all means well to examine them; among others, I caued many heads to be gently boyled in a little water, as well to conider the divers utures of the skull, and to eparate all the parts from it; as to remark well the form and the connexion of thee Glands, to draw them out whole, and joined, as they are, to the Eyes, and to divers bodies of the Brain, to which the marrow of the Spaine is annex'd; and to have all thee parts entire, and uch as I have caued them to be engraven.

Me thinks, that all thee cares, follow'd by o good ucces, may well deerve, my Dicovery of this great number of Salival Glands with all their veels, hould not be envied me by Sign. Redi; conidering I do ufficiently appear to him incapable of envying him any of thoe ine things, he hath already found, or may find hereafter in his curious re-earches.

There remains no more for me to do, me thinks, than to atisfie Sign. Redi as well concerning the Uncertainty, wherein he is
touching the Power of the Volatil Salt of Vipers for the curing of their bitings; as about the Objections, by him made againt my Experiments of the Head and Neck of a Viper, for curing Doggs bitten by it, and which I have alo thought hould be efficacious to cure men in the like cae.

He oppoes nothing to the Vertue of this Volatil Salt, but that he remits the Reader to the time he will take, Chymically to prepare this Salt, and to make the Experiment therewith. But he aith, that he hath made many tryals with the Heads and Necks of Vipers, and found firt; That, having made two great Doggs aforehand to wallow, each the head and neck of a Viper, and, afterwards caued both of them to be bitten by other Vipers, thoe Doggs dyed not: And that, having caued to be bitten two other Doggs of the ame bignes, that had eaten neither head nor neck of a Viper, they dyed neither. He aith further, that having made a Pullet to wallow one head of a Viper, and a Capon two, and caued them to be bitten, they both dyed oon after. He adds, that having the next day made ready ome heads of Vipers, he caued them to be forc'd down the throat of two little Doggs, of which he caued
the leat to be bitten in the legg near the anus, and the other, in the tongue, and that they both dyed; That he made the ame Experiment upon eight Pullets, two Kitlings, two mall Rabbets, and ix Pigeons, even with rubbing the place bitten with the blood of the Viper; That alo the ix Pigeons were bitten by the heads of Vipers, dead everal dayes before, and that all thee animals dyed; That latly, he had fed two Pigeons for there dayes with the fleh and broath of Vipers, and being bitten thereupon, they dyed likewie, this aid notwithtanding.

For Anwer to all thee Experiments, I make ue of the ame Generals, that Sign. Redi hath done againt mine, which are to be found pag. 16. of his lat Letter; where he aith: That a Viper more eaily kills leer Animals by his biting, than great ones; that, according to the bignes of the Animal bitten, and according as the place wounded is more or les provided with veins or arteries; that, if from the wound of a Viper much blood iueth, the Animal not only dyeth not, but does not o much as feel any great inconvenience; that it alo falls out ometimes, that the Animal bitten ecapeth, after it hath endured many
mortal ymptoms; and that this may come to pas by the ole aitance of Nature.

As to the two other Generals, which he alledgeth in reference to the letting in of the yellow liquor; I did not think fit to alledge them here, both becaue I agree not as to the poibility of the fact, and that I have elewhere declared my elf ufficiently about it; as alo that they make not to this purpoe. But I think it more material, to add here two other Generals to thoe of Sign. Redi, and to ay: That the biting is more or les noxious, not only according to the place bitten, but according to the degree of the Vipers being vexed when he is to bite, and according as her teeth have more or les penetrated. And reaoning particularly upon thee experiments, I ay, that the dogs which I had caued to be bitten every one thrice, & were cured by making each of them wallow the head and neck of a Viper, were of a very midling ize, that it is very difficult to found a certainjudgment upon the great ones, which Sign. Redi hath ued, as 'tis alo, to pas it upon them that had wallow'd the head and neck of a Viper, and thoe, that had not done o, that all the other little animals, which he employed, as well the Pullet and the Capon, as the Pigeons, Catlings, Puppies, and little
Rabbets, had not of themelves trength enough to reit for a time the enraged pirits, nor to find the effect of the remedy; epecially that which was bitten in the tongue. For, I firmly believe, that there is no animal, great or mal, which being fiercely bit in the tongue by a Viper well vexed, can avoid death, what aid oever you miniter to it, becaue of the nerves, veins & arteries, dieminated through the tongue; and becaue that the angred pirits finding a free entrance, produce there all the effect they are capable of, with o much violence and nimblenes, that nothing is able to top them. But in all curable bites I hall not eaily be induced to renounce the help, which may be given by the head, neck, heart, liver, and divers other parts of a Viper (epecially of her that made the bite) for the cure of the animals that have ufficient trength to reit a while, and to expect the benefit of this kind of remedy. I believe alo to have great caue not to exclude from it man himelf; as alo to prefer the parts of the ame Viper that hath bitten, to thoe of others; becaue they mut needs have greater cognation and more conent with the vexed pirits, that iued from her. Concerning which I think it not amis, to impart to the publick an accident that hapn'd in the Royal Laboratory of this City, whilt my lat experiments were making.

A young man that had made a good progres in his tudies, deirous to perfect himelf in both ways of Pharmacy, and chiefly addicted to my coure of Chymitry, was near me, in the midt of a great Aembly, on the 2d day of my experiments. After I had made ome, whilt I was entertaining the company, the fancy took him, in imitation of me, yet without my knowledge, to take a Viper with his hand, and to eize on her head: which he did not with that caution that is neceary, as not holding her o fat but that the Viper took her opportunity, and truck one of her great teeth very deep into the middle of the upper part of his left fore-finger. Having been made acquainted therewith, I remov'd, as much as I could, all fear from his pirit, and advied him to betake himelf to the neceary remedies. The credit he gave to the truths contain'd in my book, often read by him, induced him to ay, that if I thought well of it, he would eat the head and neck of the Viper that had bit him. Commending his courage, I econded his good inclinations; for, I caued lightly to be broiled on coals the head and neck of the aid viper, and made him eat and wallow it hot, in the midt of the company, adding to it the heart and liver broiled likewie. After which I aid, I doubted not but what he had done would be ufficient to cure him; yet to be the
urer, I would give him ome volatil alt of vipers, epecially he being a peron whom I did much eteem, and for whoe health I had and ever hould haue a great concern. I thereupon immediately gave him a doe a fifty grains of this volatil alt, diolved in four ounces of water, and aured him there was not any danger after this. The young man remained in the midt of the company, & tirr'd not from the place, till the meeting ended, and then he took a little freh air. He was afterwards a couple of hours in the Royal Garden and the Laboratory; during which time he now & then found ome little icknes about his heart; but being come to his own lodging, he was ready to up as he was ued to do, and would have done it, if I had not thought it better for him to take another doe of the ame volatil alt, which had o good effect, that the next day, after he had dined well, he came again to our meeting; which did much urprie all thoe that had been witnees of the bite. Since that time he hath ever been very well. Now though his wound appear'd much deeper then that of the German gentleman, that was bitten the 1t day of my former experiments; yet had he none of thoe grievous accidents, that befell him, & were by me decribed in my book: for he had no other pain but that of the hole of the bite, nor had he o much as a Fever. The wound
only rendred ome drops of blood, by means of the ligature, I caus'd to be made on the top of his wounded finger, which did never well, and heal'd up as if it had been made by the prick of a pin, without any Cicatrice appearing; o far was it from a Gangrene, or Scar, as ome fancied he would have.

The thing hath been too publick, not to be credited every where; and I think not, that Sign, Redi himelf will doubt of it; but rather that all things have concurr'd together to verifie all I had advanced in my book, of which he hath conteted ome particulars, and could not reolve himelf about others. However, if he have by him any remedies, more quick and more ure for the cure of the bites of Vipers, the publick will be much oblig'd to him when he hall pleae to impart them, as I very willingly communicate thee I have experimented. I hall not peak here of divers Experiments lately made upon Vipers by very able perons at Paris, which confirm not only the perfect innocence of the jellow liquor that is in the veicles of the Gums, but which warrant at the ame time my adcribing the venom to the enraged pirits. Thee truths will be better received from their hands, and they will be much more advantagious to me, than if I did attempt to publih them now. For doubtles there will be found in them very
curious things, and they are like to be of more importance than what I might be able to ay of them. Beides that I am far from uurping the honor due to others, and from attributing to me the obligation, which the publick will owe them for it.

For a concluion of this dicoure; ince Sign. Redi hath not found in the whole body of a Viper any other part but the jellow juice to which he can aign its venom; ince on my part by the new experiments, he hath deir'd of me, I have ufficiently jutified the innocence of the jellow liquor in the Vipers of France, and the great conformities, there mut needs be in the ame with that of the Vipers of Italy, aerting withal the venomonnes of the angred pirits cauing the death that enueth the bite; and ince latly the Vipers of France do kill as oon and in the ame manner as thoe of Italy do, and even without any intervention of the jellow liquor: Thee things being o, I eteem, that Sign. Redi would do very well, if, to atisfie on his part the expectation of the publick, and without adhering any longer to the jellow liquor, which is o reaonably conteted, he would take the pains to labour to find out ome new ubject, that might be common to the Vipers of France and thoe of Italy; that might have the ame dipoition of matter, and the ame
power of acting nimbly; and that might with reaon be equally declared the true eat of their venom; to the end that afterwards he might as jutly exclude from it the enraged pirits, as I now exclude from it the jellow liquor. But if on the contrary it comes to pas, that he can find none other, I believe not, that for the future he hath any ground to maintain his opinion, no more than to contet mine.

Concluding this diertation I hall ay, that the contrariety of opinions, which is between Sign. Redi and me, in the mot eential things of the Vipers poion, may alo be oberved upon another account about the ame animal: For, the more he expreeth p. 39. of his lat letter, the averion and hatred he hath againt it, the more I eteem it, and the greater pleaure I take to handle, to examine, and to prepare it. Nor can I ufficiently praie the excellent qualities, which o rare a ubject poeeth, nor the admirable remedies which it furniheth: Which are the coniderations, that have heretofore induced me, and oblige me till to call the Viper one of the chief Pillars of Phyick.

It may be, that for this once Sign. Redi will not doubt but that a dicoure as rude as this, compos'd among coals and furnaces, which I have eldom quitted of late, is mine. He will doubtles judge, that, if more undertanding men had put their hands to it, the reaonings thereof
would be more ubtile, the tyle more polite, and the expreions more elegant; and the Greek and Latin quotations would not have been pared therein, both to trengthen the arguments thereof, and to adorn & enlarge the volume. But for all the contrarieties, which the different conceptions have bred between Sign. Redi and me, I hall always have a very great and a very diinterre'd eteem for him; and o much the more, becaue I have great reaon to conceive ome good opinion of my book, ince it could deerve that o intelligent & famous a peron hath vouchafed to read it again and again with pleaure, as he aith himelf, that he hath taken the pains of trancribing many pages out of it word for word, and hath made it famous by his anwer, and by that alo which a peron of great parts, and a high reputation hath made to it, addres'd to himelf on this ubject. I cannot but much glory in it, and highly declare my elf his obliged. And if it hould come to pas, that the diverity of his experiments, the force of his arguments, or the eteem he hath acquired among the Learned, hould carry the bell from me in the pirits of all the world; the victory, which he hould thence obtain, would not be much les advantagious for me, then if the truth of my experiments, accompanied by my reaonings, had been able to ballance or even to prevail over his Sentiments and the writings of o Illutrious a Peron.
